For the safety of passengers, a portion of the track was closed. Subsequent investigations by explosive experts revealed that the device was a training aid. Normal railway operations have been resumed. We thank passengers for their patience during the investigation.

Thanks for joining us.

There has been no election again of an assembly speaker, which means no restoration of the power-sharing institutions.

Attention will now switch to Northern Ireland Secretary Chris Heaton-Harris who is under a legal duty to call an early assembly election if no executive is formed by Thursday.

But he has already pushed this deadline back several times before.

We'll keep you up to date with the latest twists and turns - or lack thereof - at Stormont on the BBC News NI website.

Defender Riccardo Calafiori is set to have his medical with Arsenal as his move from Bologna edges closer.

The Gunners intend for the Italy international, 22, to join the squad for their pre-season tour of the United States.

Arsenal are in Los Angeles for Wednesday's match against Bournemouth and face Manchester United on Saturday.

They then head to Philadelphia to play Liverpool on 31 July.

Calafiori scored two goals and registered five assists in 30 Serie A appearances last season, helping Bologna claim a fifth-placed finish and a spot in next season's Champions League.

He started in all three of Italy's group-stage games at Euro 2024 before they fell to Switzerland in the last 16.

A graduate from Roma's academy, Calafiori joined Swiss side Basel in 2022 before a £3.3m move to Bologna the following season.

After that, they will travel to Philadelphia to face Liverpool on July 31.

Calafiori came from Roma's youth academy and joined Basel in 2022 before being transferred to Bologna to pay a transfer fee of £3.3 million.

0.text:
Just over a month ago, you probably hadn't heard of Jay Slater.

He was a teenager on a first holiday without his parents in Tenerife, like so many Brits this summer.

Sometimes accidents happen while abroad and occasionally they become tragedies. Few ever hear about them.

Not for Jay, 19, whose family have been thrust into a national spotlight during a month-long search that has captivated millions of people on social media.

Yet the facts in Jay's case now seem relatively simple. He got lost in treacherous terrain and fell to his death.

His family hoped the viral frenzy would end when his body was found last week. But it did not.

Many are now asking one question: why did it take 29 days to find him?

We’ve spent time in Tenerife over the past month inside the search for Jay, reporting on the riddle.

What we've seen raises both questions and answers.

2.text:
About a month ago, you were unlikely to have known about Jay Slater.

He was an 19-year-old British man who spent his first holiday without parents in Tenerife, this summer.

Sometimes accidents happen during foreign stays and sometimes they escalate into tragedies. Most people never hear about these.

But not for Jay, whose family in the past four weeks has captured public attention and millions on social media.

The facts in Jay's case seem relatively simple. He got lost in dangerous terrain and died from a fall.

His family had hoped that the viral whirlwind interest following the discovery of his body two weeks ago would have subsided. But that was not the case.

Now many are asking: Why did it take 29 days to find him?

We have spent the past four weeks in Tenerife searching for Jay and reported on what we saw.

What we saw raises questions and provides answers.

4.text:

We expected a fiery day on Paula Vennells' last day at the inquiry, and that's what we got.

The former Post Office CEO faced questions from a several lawyers representing sub-postmasters, who did not hold back.

'You preach compassion but don't practice it,' one said right at the beginning.

The room was jam packed - I saw a couple of people actually looking for spare seats in the chamber. There was sarcastic laughter each time Vennells said she was not involved in the scandal, and the audience scoffed at her apologies.

One sub-postmaster told me he actually felt some sympathy for her during the first half of the day.

But things changed after lunch, when Tim Moloney took over questioning.

The most significant moment was when the audience booed Vennells for apologising for an email in which she said she was 'bored' listening to sub-postmasters on television, and that Jo Hamilton - who was in the room - 'lacked passion'.

By then, someone seated nearby told me, there was no sympathy left.

Thank you for joining us today. We will be closing our live page shortly. You can read more about today's events here and about the Horizon scandal here.

Emergency services were called on Saturday to a farm in the Warcop area

An eight-year-old boy who died after being shot in the head and face at a farm has been named as Jay Cartmell. The boy, from Frizington, in west Cumbria, was injured on land near the A66, north of Warcop, nearly 60 miles away, at about 14:50 BST on Saturday and later died in hospital. A man in his 60s who was being held on suspicion of gross negligence manslaughter was released on bail. A Cumbria police spokesman said the firearm 'was secured at the scene'.

Officers said they were continuing to investigate the circumstances and encouraged anyone who may have witnessed the incident or the moments leading up to it to come forward.
• None Boy, 8, dies after being shot in the head at farm

He later died in the hospital. A man in his 60s, suspected of manslaughter, was released on bail. The authorities secured the weapon at the crime scene.

The investigation is making progress. Anyone with information regarding this incident or the lead-up events is urged to contact the authorities.

A wildfire fanned by winds of up to 80mph (130km/h) is burning out of control in California's Ventura County.

The fire was first reported near Moorpark, 40 miles northwest of Los Angeles, early on Wednesday.

Within hours it had reached a suburb of Camarillo, a city of 70,000 people around 10 miles away.

Thousands of residents have been forced to flee and several have been reported injured.

Ventura County Fire Chief Dustin Gardner said that the fire was moving 'dangerously fast' and destroying everything in its path.

'Bushes are burning, grass is burning, hedgerows are burning, agricultural fields are burning, and structures are burning,' he said.

The fire was first reported near Moorpark, about 40 miles northwest of Los Angeles, on Thursday morning.

Within hours, it had reached a suburb of Camarillo, a city with 70,000 residents, which is approximately 10 miles away.

Thousands of residents had to be evacuated, and injuries were reported.

The chief of the Ventura County Fire Department, Dustin Gardner, stated, 'The fire is extremely dangerous and destroys everything in its path.'

'Shrubs are burning, grass is burning, hedges are burning, agricultural fields are burning, and buildings are burning,' he said.

Mini was rescued after a BBC Eye investigation that exposed a global online monkey torture ring.

She was taken from the forest after her mother was killed. Her owner tortured her and filmed it for sadistic customers mainly in the US and the UK, before she was rescued.

After two years of rehabilitation at a sanctuary run by the Jakarta Animal Aid Network, Mini and her adopted family were deemed ready to return to the wild.

BBC World Service reporter Rebecca Henschke – who spent over a year tracking Mini and her torturers down – went along for her release.

You can watch the full story on iPlayer in the UK and for international viewers on BBC World Service YouTube., external

And read more here: Hunting the monkey torturers.

2.text:
The BBC's Eye investigation uncovered a global monkey smuggling organization online.

She was taken from the forest after her mother was killed. Her owner mistreated her and filmed it primarily for sadistic customers in the USA and the UK, before she was rescued.

After two years of rehabilitation at the Jakarta Animal Aid Network's animal welfare facility, Mini and her adopted family were ready to return to the wild.

BBC World Service Journalist Rebecca Henschke, who had been following Mini and her perpetrators for over a year, accompanied her release.

You can watch the whole thing on iPlayer in the UK and on YouTube for international viewers of the BBC World Service. extern

Read more here: Hunt for Monkey Smugglers.

0.text:
Meanwhile the Campaign group A5: Enough is Enough is continuing to push for the dual carriageway project to go ahead as soon as possible.

As well as the safety aspect, economic benefits have often been cited as a key priority of a new A5 dual carriageway.

As part of the public inquiry process, DFI published a redacted version of a business case for the proposed new A5 dual carriageway.

The report pointed to a legacy of underinvestment and poor connectivity in the area, as well as journey times being made unreliable by congestion caused at bottlenecks at junctions in key towns.

“There is a direct line between having a safe and fit for purpose A5 and the trading success and good jobs ambitions of the west. The A5 upgrade is therefore one of the most important strategic economic investments.”

2.text:
In the meantime, the A5 campaign continues: Enough is enough, the new construction of the A5 autobahn must be continued as quickly as possible.

Besides the aspect of safety, economic advantages are often cited as a priority for the new A5 autobahn two-lane highway.

Within the framework of public hearing procedures, DFI published a redacted version of a business case for the proposed new A5 autobahn two-lane highway.

The document pointed to a past of underfunded investments and poor connections in the region, as well as unreliable travel times due to traffic jams at key urban intersections.

'There is a direct connection between safety and a functioning A5 and successful trade and good employment opportunities in the west. The modernization of the A5 is therefore one of the most important strategic economic investments.'

4.text:
In the meantime, the A5 campaign continues to progress: Enough is enough, the renovation of the A5 motorway must be resumed as soon as possible.

Besides safety aspects, economic advantages are often cited as a priority for the new two-way A5 motorway.

In the context of legal hearing procedures, DFI has published a redacted version of a business case for the proposed new two-way A5 motorway.

The document refers to a past history of underfinanced investments and poor connections in the region, as well as unreliable travel times due to traffic jams at major urban intersections.

'There is a direct link between safety and a functioning A5 and successful business relationships and good employment opportunities in the west. The modernization of the A5 is therefore one of the most important strategic economic investments.'

Translation:

As time goes on, the A5 campaign continues: Enough is enough, the renovation of the A5 motorway must be resumed as soon as possible.

Safety concerns and economic benefits are often cited as priorities for the new two-way A5 motorway.

In the context of legal hearing procedures, DFI has published a redacted version of a business case for the proposed new two-way A5 motorway.

The document refers to a past history of underfunded investments and poor connections in the region, as well as unreliable travel times due to traffic jams at major urban intersections.

'There is a direct connection between safety and a functioning A5 and successful business relationships and good employment opportunities in the west. The modernization of the A5 is therefore one of the most important strategic economic investments.'

Border Force staff at Heathrow Airport had been due to go on strike in a dispute over shift patterns

A strike by Border Force staff at Heathrow Airport has been suspended.

Members of the Public and Commercial Services union (PCS) were due to walk out for four days from 11 April over changes in shift patterns.

PCS general secretary Fran Heathcote said 'this does not end the dispute' but the Home Office could show it was 'genuinely seeking a resolution'.

Before the walkout was called off, the Home Office had said it had 'robust plans' to minimise delays.

The shift changes could cause job losses, the union said.

Ms Heathcote added: 'If the Home Office does not engage in meaningfully addressing members' grievances, strikes will be resumed and further escalated.'

Listen to the best of BBC Radio London on Sounds and follow BBC London on Facebook, X and Instagram. Send your story ideas to hello.bbclondon@bbc.co.uk

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.

2.text:
Border force workers at Heathrow Airport had planned a strike due to shift patterns.

The planned strike of border force workers at Heathrow Airport has been cancelled.

Members of the Public and Commercial Services Union (PCS) had intended to strike for four days, starting on the 11th of April, due to changes in shift patterns.

The PCS union chair, Fran Heathcote, said: 'This does not end the dispute, but the Home Office could demonstrate that it is 'earnestly seeking solutions'.'

Before the strike was cancelled, the Home Office had announced plans to minimize delays with 'robust' measures.

The shift pattern changes could result in job losses, the union stated.

Ms Heathcote added: 'Should the Home Office not seriously address the concerns of its members, strikes will be resumed and escalated.'

0.text:
On 2 August 2022 Taiwan television channels began live tracking a US government jet heading north across the South China Sea on course for Taiwan. On board was then US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi.

Thousands turned out to watch her plane touch down at Taipei’s old Songshan airport. The following day at the presidential office, she was presented with one of Taiwan’s highest state honors.

To a place so starved of international recognition there was much to celebrate. Not since 1996 had such a high-profile serving US politician touched Taiwan soil.

But there would be a price. China kicked off its biggest-ever military exercises in the seas around Taiwan following her visit.

Days after her plane departed Song Shan air-base, Japan reported it was tracking multiple Chinese missiles heading towards the island.

Taiwan's defence ministry was strangely silent. Only later did it admit that for the first time ever China had fired ballistic missiles over the top of the island, into the Pacific Ocean.

2.text:
On August 2, 2022, Taiwanese television stations began live broadcasting a US government aircraft flying northward through the South Pacific Ocean towards Taiwan, with Nancy Pelosi, then US Speaker of the House, on board.

Over 3000 people gathered at the old Songshan Airport in Taipei to witness their landing. The following day, she was honored at the Presidential Palace with one of the highest Taiwanese state awards.

Such a significant international recognition position was worth celebrating. It had been over 20 years since a US politician of such high rank stood on Taiwanese soil.

However, there were costs. China conducted its largest-ever military drills in the seas surrounding Taiwan in response to her visit.

After Pelosi's aircraft took off from Song Shan Airbase, Japan reported the sighting of Chinese rockets heading towards the island.

Taiwan's Defense Ministry initially remained silent. Later, it confirmed that China had, for the first time, fired ballistic missiles over the island and into the Pacific Ocean.

George Clooney has praised Joe Biden's decision to quit the presidential race as the most selfless thing a president has done since George Washington.

The actor, who is one of the Democratic Party's leading fundraisers, had previously urged Mr Biden not to seek re-election in an opinion piece in the New York Times.

He said the president was a shadow of his former self, writing 'we are not going to win in November with this president.'

0.text:
Hyperia was closed the day after it first opened in May

The UK’s tallest rollercoaster has reopened after another breakdown halted rides. Riders were stuck on board Hyperia, at Thorpe Park in Surrey, for an hour on Saturday. The ride was closed for the rest of the day. It reopened at 10:00 BST on Sunday, with queue times at about 90 minutes, according to the park’s app. Hyperia first launched on 24 May but was closed the following day until 12 June while staff carried out a number of technical safety checks.

The ride is 236ft (72m) in height and has a top speed of 81mph (130km/h). In a statement on Saturday the theme park said there were no safety concerns for the people temporarily stuck on Hyperia. Thorpe Park said: 'Guests were held on the lift hill for approximately one hour before the ride was restarted and the train was brought back into the ride station. 'Stoppages are perfectly normal and commonly experienced in theme parks everywhere.”

Follow BBC Surrey on Facebook, external and on X, external. Send your story ideas to southeasttoday@bbc.co.uk and WhatsApp us on 08081 002250.

2.text:
Hyperia resumed operation on the day following its opening in May

The tallest roller coaster model in Britain has been back in service, after a defect halted rides. Passengers were stranded on Hyperia at Thorpe Park in Surrey for approximately an hour on a Saturday. The ride remained closed for the rest of the day. It reopened again at 10:00 BST on Sunday with estimated wait times of approximately 90 minutes, as per the park app. Hyperia made its debut on May 24th but was closed until June 12th while employees conducted various technical safety inspections.

The ride stands at a height of 72m (236ft) and reaches a top speed of 130km/h (81mph). In a statement on Saturday, the amusement park stated, 'Guests were kept waiting on the lift for approximately an hour before the ride was restarted and the train returned to the ride station.'

Rene, 31, suffered severe injuries and could not be saved

A chimpanzee has died at Edinburgh Zoo after it was severely injured in a troop fight. Staff tried to intervene to separate the primates but they were unable to save 31-year-old Rene. A second chimpanzee was also injured during the incident last week and had to be operated on. A zoo spokesperson said: 'This type of behaviour occurs in the wild, especially around breeding time when females are in season and when males are challenging for dominance of the group.'

A second chimpanzee, Qafzeh, required an operation for his injuries. He is said to be doing well and is gradually being reintroduced to the group. The statement concluded: 'Rene was a huge personality and will be missed by those who cared for him.' Edinburgh Zoo, which is run by the Royal Zoological Society of Scotland, is home to 15 chimpanzees. The primates live in one enclosure called the Budongo Trail.

Several front pages focus on the early release of prisoners in England and Wales. The Daily Telegraph has a photo of a heavily tattooed offender, giving the thumbs-up , externalas he was freed from Durham jail. 'Cheers, Keir' is the headline. The paper's cartoonist, Matt, addresses concerns about rehabilitation. He depicts inmates leaving a prison under a sign saying: 'Thank you for staying. See you again soon.' There is a picture on the front of the Daily Mail of a prisoner at Nottingham jail being sprayed with champagne, external - described in the caption as 'sickening celebrations'. The Mail lists other incidents it is outraged by, including one offender being 'greeted by friends in a Lamborghini', and another vowing he's now a 'life-long Labour voter'. The Sun dismisses the release scheme as a 'day of shame for the justice system'. , externalBut its opinion column acknowledges that the circumstances which have led to it are 'not all the new government's fault'. It points out that the overcrowding 'dates back at least to Tony Blair's era'.

Sign up for our morning newsletter and get BBC News in your inbox.

2.text:
Multiple front pages show early releases from prison sentences in England and Wales. The Daily Telegraph front page depicts a heavily tattooed offender being released from Durham Prison, raising his hand. The headline reads: 'Yes, Keir.' The Daily Telegraph cartoonist, Matt, expresses concerns about rehabilitation in his drawing. He shows prisoners leaving the prison under a sign that reads: 'Thank you for your stay. We'll see you soon.' The Daily Mail front page features a photo of a prisoner being sprayed with champagne at Nottingham Prison, described outside as 'alleged celebrations.' The Mail lists further incidents, causing alarm, such as a criminal being received by friends in a Lamborghini and one identifying as a 'lifelong Labour voter.' The Sun's editorial condemns the release program as a 'disgrace of the justice system,' but its opinion columnist, who is not involved, recognizes that the circumstances leading to it are not only the responsibility of the new government. They point to overcrowding 'at least since the Blair era.'

'Sign up for our Morning Newsletter and get BBC News in your inbox.' (Translation: 'Subscribe to our Morning Newsletter and receive BBC News via email.')

On Friday, Donald Trump took a break from hush-money trial proceedings in New York to attend Barron Trump's high school graduation ceremony in West Palm Beach, Florida.

In photos and videos taken from outside the event venue, Donald and Melania Trump can be seen applauding for Oxbridge Academy's class of 2024.

Barron Trump rarely appeared in public during the Trump presidency, with his mother reported to be fiercely protective of his privacy.

In an interview, Mr Trump said his son, who is reportedly considering attending college at New York University (NYU), likes politics.'It's sort of funny,' he told Philadelphia's Talk Radio 1210 WPHT. 'He'll tell me sometimes, 'Dad, this is what you have to do.''

2.text:
Thursday, Donald Trump postponed the court proceedings regarding hush money in New York the day before, to attend the graduation ceremony of the Oxbridge Academy's Class of 2024 in West Palm Beach, Florida.

Outside the event, photos and videos were shown of Donald and Melania Trump joyfully among the graduating students.

During the Trump presidency, Barron Trump was seldom in the public eye, and it was reported that his mother fiercely protected his privacy.

In an interview with Philadelphia's Talk Radio 1210 WPHT, Mr. Trump mentioned that his son, who was rumored to be studying at New York University (NYU), was politically interested: 'It's crazy,' he said. 'He tells me sometimes: 'Dad, you have to do that.''

0.text:
Housing is a priority area on which this government will be judged at the next election. A long-promised, but much-delayed, ban on no-fault evictions is included and now imminent.

The Renters’ Rights Bill, covering England, also includes Labour manifesto pledges to end manufactured rental bidding wars and allow tenants to request keeping a pet – which a landlord could not unreasonably refuse.

There will also be an extension of social housing safety rules, known as Awaab’s Law, into the private rental sector. Expect the detail of all this to be heavily scrutinised, not least by the House of Lords.

Campaigners want legislation to block any potential loopholes that would allow landlords to kick out tenants by the back door.

Landlords are pleading for a properly functioning court system to process justified evictions. On the day official data shows rents rising at a near-record 8.6% a year, they warn any exodus from the sector would reduce supply and increase the cost of renting at an even faster rate.

2.text:
particularly by the House of Lords.

Activists are advocating for laws to prevent landlords from abandoning tenants.

Landlords are urging for an efficient court administration to process justified evictions. On the day when official data reveals that rent prices are growing at almost record annual rates of 8.6%, they caution that an exodus from the sector could decrease supply and cause rent prices to escalate even more rapidly.

Translation:

Housing is a priority area where this government is highly regarded for the upcoming election. A long-promised, but now imminent, ban on eviction without fault grounds is included.

The Renting Reforms Bill for England encompasses Labour election pledges to put an end to contrived rent bidding between tenants and require landlords to allow tenants to keep pets – which a landlord can unreasonably refuse.

There will also be an extension of social housing security regulations, known as Awaab's Law, into the private rental sector. The details of all this will be meticulously reviewed, especially by the House of Lords.

Activists are campaigning for laws to prevent landlords from abandoning tenants.

Landlords are appealing for an effective court administration to process justified evictions. On the day when official data shows that rent prices are increasing at nearly record annual rates of 8.6%, they issue a warning that an exodus from the sector could diminish supply and cause rent prices to surge even more rapidly.

4.text:
In the living quarters, this government is highly respected, prioritizing it for the upcoming elections. A long-awaited, nearly immediate ban on expropriations without negligent reasons is included.

The Housing Reform Act for England covers the Labour Party's election promises, such as ending artificial rent bids among tenants and allowing tenants to keep pets – which can lead to disproportionate rejections by the landlord.

Additionally, an introduction of extended social housing security regulations, known as the Awaabs Law, is being implemented in the private rental market. All details are being closely examined, especially by the House of Lords.

Activists are calling for laws to prevent landlords from expropriating tenants.

Landlords are appealing for an effective court administration to process justified expropriations. On the day official data shows that rent prices indicate nearly record-high annual increases of 8.6%, they issue a warning that they may withdraw from the sector and thus reduce supply and further increase rent prices.

British number one Katie Boulter missed out on a place in the Pan Pacific Open final after a straight-set defeat by American wildcard Sofia Kenin in Saturday's semi-finals.

The 28-year-old had been aiming to win her third title of the year but lost 6-4 6-4 in Tokyo in one hour and 30 minutes to the former world number four.

Boulter was broken twice in the first set and, although she recovered one of the breaks when Kenin first served for the set, she was unable to break again and the 2020 Australian Open champion secured the set at the second time of asking.

Kenin had to save four break points in the sixth game of the second set but held on to make it 3-3 and broke the Briton in the following game, maintaining her advantage after that to reach the final.

She will face top seed Zheng Qinwen of China in the showpiece after the Olympic champion defeated sixth seed Diana Shnaider from Russia 7-6 (7-5) 6-3.

It is the second time Zheng has reached the final of the tournament, after she was beaten by Liudmila Samsonova in 2022.

2.text:
Katie Boulter, the highest-ranked British player, lost in the final of the Pan Pacific Open against Sofia Kenin after being defeated in straight sets in the Saturday semifinals.

The 28-year-old had prepared for the win of her third title of the year, but she lost 6:4, 4:6 in one hour and thirty minutes against the former world No. 3 in Tokyo.

Boulter was served 17 times in the first set and managed to convert only one of these serving opportunities, when Kenin was at the net for the first time to receive the ball. She broke again and secured the second set.

Kenin had to defend against four break point opportunities in the sixth game of the second set, but she held on to even the score at 3:3. She broke the Brit in the following game and secured the lead and a spot in the final.

She faces the top-seeded Zheng Qinwen from China in the final phase, who defeated Garbiñe Muguruza, the Spanish Olympian, in the semifinals with a score of 7:6 (7:5), 3:6, 6:3.

This is the second time Zheng has reached the final of the tournament, having been defeated by Liudmila Samsonova in 2022.

The BT Tower’s revolving restaurant was once famous for the panoramic views it provided of London.

At first the public were able to visit the top-floor restaurant, which opened in 1966 and was run by Billy Butlin of holiday camp fame.

The viewing platform was closed to the public after a bomb exploded there in 1971. This, coupled with the lease from Butlin’s ending, meant the restaurant was closed to the public in 1980, restricting the venue to invitation-only for special occasions.

It was announced on Wednesday that the BT Group had sold the tower for £275m to MCR Hotels, and now architectural heritage campaign group C20 says it hopes to see the revolving restaurant reinstated.

In 2002, former postmaster general Tony Benn explored the restaurant he had visited on many previous occasions.

From: Afoot again in the past, 2002

The viewing platform was sealed off to the public following a bomb explosion there in 1971. With the expiration of Butlin's lease and this incident, the restaurant was shut down for the public and utilized only for special events.

On Thursday, it was disclosed that the BT Group had sold the tower for £275m to MCR Hotels, and now the architectural heritage organization C20 is optimistic about restoring the revolving restaurant.

In 2002, Tony Benn, former postmaster general, paid another visit to the restaurant, which he had attended on various previous occasions.

After its closure in 1971 due to a bomb warning, the platform was inaccessible to the public. With the expiration of Butlin's lease and that incident, the restaurant level was made accessible to the public again and is now used only for special events.

It was announced on a Thursday that the BT Company had sold the tower for 2.75 billion £ to MCR Hotels, and the C20 Society, a society for the preservation of cultural heritage, is working on the restoration of the viewing platform.

Tony Benn, who was once a postman, visited the restaurant again in 2002, a place he had been to on numerous earlier occasions.

The former subpostmistress, Seema Misra, who was jailed for 15 months over the Horizon IT, has rejected an apology from a former Post Office boss who at the time of her conviction called it 'brilliant news'.

Speaking to the BBC after the Inquiry session this morning, Misra said: 'How can I accept the apology? They need to apologise to my 10-year-old, they took his mum away on his birthday.

“I was eight weeks pregnant - they need to apologise to my youngest son. It was terrible. I haven't accepted the apologies,' she added.

David Smith told the inquiry this morning that in hindsight his email about Misra's case was 'poorly thought through'.

'Brilliant news. Well done. Please pass on my thanks to the team,' Smith said in a 2010 email to colleagues.

Misra was handed a 15-month jail term while being eight weeks pregnant.

She had been wrongly accused of stealing £70,000 from her Post Office branch in the village of West Byfleet in Surrey and was sent to Bronzefield prison on the day of her eldest son's 10th birthday.

A parrot's 'amazing' impersonation of a smoke alarm led to firefighters being called out to a home.

A crew arrived at the property in Daventry, Northamptonshire, after the alarm was heard three times.

They cleaned out a smoke detector at the home, but heard the noise again and discovered the 'alarm' was coming from one of two pet grey parrots mimicking the sound.

Owner Steve Dockerty, 63, pulled an emergency alarm cord to alert his carers when he heard what he thought was the smoke alarm.

He said: 'Jazz loves to imitate things and he imitated a smoke alarm so well, they called the fire brigade.'

2.text:
In a household in Daventry, Northamptonshire, a pair of Parakeets triggered an alarming sound from the smoke detector, drawing the attention of the fire department.

The team arrived at the building after hearing the tone three times.

They removed a smoke detector from the house, but heard the tone again and discovered that the 'alarm' was two gray Capuchin monkeys mimicking the sequence.

Owner Steve Dockerty, 63, pulled the emergency alarm cord to alert his caretakers, believing it was the smoke detector alarm.

He said: 'Jazz loves mimicking things and he mimicked the smoke detector alarm so accurately that the fire department was called.'

Mike Phillips has been banned from driving after pleading guilty to drink-driving

Rugby star Mike Phillips has been handed a 25-month ban after admitting drink-driving. The 41-year-old former Wales international was three times over the limit when he was arrested in Llanwrtyd Wells, Powys, on 7 July. Llandrindod Wells Magistrates’ Court heard on Wednesday the former scrum half - who gave the court his full name as William Mike Phillips - was in an Audi A4 when the offence happened. The court was told 108 micrograms of alcohol per 100ml of breath was recorded in a reading. The legal limit is 35.

The ban will be cut by 25 weeks, if Phillips, who also represented the British and Irish Lions, finishes an awareness course by 8 January 2026. Phillips was also fined £1,153 and ordered to pay £461 surcharge and £85 costs.

2.text:
Mike Phillips received a sentence of 25 months' imprisonment for driving under the influence of alcohol. The rugby star admitted to the offense, which occurred on July 7, 2025 in Llanwrtyd Wells, Powys. The court in Llandrindod Wells learned on Thursday that the former halfback, who identified himself as William Mike Phillips in court, was driving an Audi A4 at the time of the incident. The court was informed that 108 milligrams of alcohol per 100 ml of breath were detected. The limit is 35.

The sentence will be reduced by 25 weeks if Phillips, who has also played for the British and Irish Lions, participates in a rehabilitation program by January 8, 2026. In addition, Phillips was ordered to pay a fine of 1,153 £ and costs of 461 £.

The rugby star identified himself in court on July 7, 2025 in Llanwrtyd Wells, Powys, as Michael William Phillips. The court in Llandrindod Wells learned on Thursday that Phillips, who identified himself as Michael William Phillips in court, was driving an Opel Audi A4 at that time. The court clerk reported that 108 milligrams of alcohol per liter of breath were found. The limit is 35.

The prison sentence will be reduced by 25 weeks if Phillips, who has also played for the British and Irish Lions, participates in a rehabilitation program by January 8, 2026. In addition, Phillips was ordered to pay £1,153 in costs.

The fastest lap time was set by Perez, Verstappen's teammate, followed by George Russell of Mercedes and the Ferraris of Leclerc and Sainz.

The top 10 were completed by Lance Stroll of Aston Martin and Alex Albon of Williams.

Verstappen was 0.577 seconds behind Hamilton in the session on the Jeddah Street Circuit, the second longest race track of the season after Belgium's Spa-Francorchamps.

The training took place in daylight, while the qualifying and races were planned for Monday and Thursday to conclude the race weekend before the beginning of the Islamic holy month of Ramadan.

There were further developments in the ongoing controversy over allegations against Christian Horner, the boss of the Red Bull Formula 1 team.

Red Bull dismissed the employee who made the allegations against Horner, who had already been let go.

After an internal investigation, the allegations against Christian Horner, the CEO and team principal of Red Bull Formula 1, were dropped.

My pain will last forever, says victim's sister

Reina St Juliana said she did not get the chance to say goodbye to Hana, her little sister. At 14, her life had only just begun. 'I can never do Hana justice by talking about her,' she said, praising her incandescence, joy, humour and ability to connect people. 'More than anything, she makes you feel seen.' 'I've never known pain that could last forever until I saw Hana in a casket,' she continued. 'Our 10-year-old little brother had to learn how to write a eulogy for his sister before he even learned how to write essays.' The 14-year-old had debuted on the women's basketball team only the day before the shooting, she said, and she never got to see future birthdays, school dances and so many other milestones. Most of the shots fired that day hit Hana, she said.

One of Britain's most distinguished and versatile actors, the late Timothy West had strong connections to Bristol and the wider West Country.

On Tuesday, the actor's children announced in a statement, external that he had died peacefully in his sleep at the age of 90. His family, colleagues and celebrities have paid tribute to the star who was known for his roles on stage and screen.

West was born in Bradford but grew up in Bristol, attending Bristol Grammar School. He was awarded an honorary degree by the University of Bristol in 2017.

Outside of acting, West championed the restoration of parts of the Kennet and Avon Canal alongside his wife, the actress Prunella Scales.

The couple appeared together in the long-running Channel 4 series Great Canal Journeys.

West referred to the Caen Hill flight of locks in Wiltshire as 'amazing' and was also a supporter of the campaign to restore Birnbeck Pier in Weston-super-Mare, Somerset.

An arrest warrant has been issued for Kansas City Chiefs wide receiver Rashee Rice after he was involved a hit-and-run crash that injured four people.

Police in Dallas, Texas, said two speeding cars, a Lamborghini and Corvette, caused 'a chain reaction collision' on 30 March.

Rice faces eight charges, including aggravated assault and collision involving serious bodily injury.

Reports, external say the 23-year-old plans to hand himself in.

Last week Rice, who was driving the Lamborghini, apologised for his role in the crash, saying he took 'full responsibility' and would co-operate with authorities.

Police told the BBC the occupants of both speeding cars ran from the scene of the crash.

Police said Theodore Knox, 21, was driving the Corvette and is also the subject of an arrest warrant on the same charges. His attorney said, external they have 'fully co-operated with law enforcement'.

Two drivers were treated at the scene for minor injuries and two motorists in another vehicle were taken to a local hospital.

Rice was drafted to the NFL in 2023 and played in the Chiefs' second consecutive Super Bowl victory in February.

Two men have been charged after a Banksy artwork was stolen from a central London art gallery, the Met Police has said.

CCTV footage obtained by the BBC shows the moment the artwork was stolen from the gallery.

An investigation was launched after a burglary at Grove Gallery on New Cavendish Street at about 23:00 BST on Sunday.

The work, Girl with Balloon, was the only item stolen and has since been recovered.

Larry Fraser, 47, of Evelyn Denington Road, Beckton, and James Love, 53, of Elvin Drive, North Stifford, appeared at Wimbledon Magistrates' Court on Thursday, a Met spokesperson said.

The pair are set to appear at Kingston Crown Court on 9 October.

The CCTV footage obtained by the BBC shows the moment the painting was taken from the gallery.

The theft occurred around 23:00 BST on Sunday evening and triggered an investigation.

Only Banksy's painting 'Girl with Ballon' was stolen. It was later found.

0.text:
The BBC has seen a copy of a statement sent by the head of Bancroft's School, Simon Marshall, to parents. In it, Marshall writes that Daniel was a 'much-loved' member of the school.

'I had been intending to write to you once the news has become public, but I understand that many within our community may already be aware of events yesterday,' the statement says.

'It is therefore with great sadness and shock that I am writing to inform you of the tragic death of Daniel Anjorin, one of our pupils.

'Our thoughts and prayers at this moment are with Daniel’s family and friends.

'More details will be forthcoming over the coming hours and days, but for now, our focus is on supporting the members of our community and particularly those who knew Daniel well.'

The statement adds that 'it seems scarcely believable that less than a year on from the terrible death of Grace O’Malley-Kumar in the Nottingham attacks we are facing fresh sorrow'.

The school's flag is at half-mast today Image caption: The school's flag is at half-mast today

2.text:
The BBC has shared with us a copy of a letter from Simon Marshall, headmaster of Bancroft's Schools. In it, Marshall writes that Daniel was a 'very beloved' student of the school.

I had originally intended to write as soon as the news became known, but I understand that many in our community may already have learned of this event.

It is with great sadness and shock that I must share the news that Daniel Anjorin, one of our students, has tragically passed away.

Our thoughts and prayers are with Daniel's family and friends during this difficult time.

Further details will follow in the hours and days to come, but for now, our focus is on supporting our community, especially those who knew Daniel well.

The school flag flies at half mast today.

The statement adds that 'it is almost unbelievable that less than a year after the terrible deaths of Grace O’Malley-Kumar in the Nottingham attacks, we are once again mourning.'

Chapter: The school flag flies at half mast.

0.text:
Australia sealed victory in their three-Test series against England as they won the decider 69-56 in Bendigo, Victoria.

Jess Thirlby's England side were full of confidence going into the game after their impressive 61-59 win in Sydney on Sunday.

But world champions Australia put on a clinical display, outscoring the Roses in every quarter to set up a convincing win.

'It is disappointing we couldn't back up such a strong performance in Sydney,' England captain Fran Williams told Fox Sports.

'I know a few of us will feel we have let ourselves down today. We maybe let them get on top of us and outmuscle us.

'But I am just super proud of the effort. Winning last week was massive in our history. Doing that in front of an Australian crowd, which is a hard place to come and play.

'I feel like some of our young guns have stood up and that is really exciting.'

Australia goal attack Kiera Austin was named player of the match after shooting 24 goals and a further 15 goal assists.

England now head to New Zealand for another three-match series, which starts in Auckland on Sunday.

2.text:
Australia won the three-Test series against England with a result of 69:56 in Bendigo, Victoria.

The English side, coached by Jess Thirlby, was full of confidence after their win in Sydney with a score of 61:59.

But the World Champions from Australia gave a precise performance and dominated every quarter, overpowering the Roses to achieve a convincing result.

'It's disappointing that we repeated ourselves in Sydney,' England captain Fran Williams told Fox Sports.

'Some of us may have doubted ourselves. We could have done better.

'But I'm very proud of our effort. Winning in the past was a big step for us in our history. Playing in an Australian setting, which is a challenging environment, makes me proud.

'I believe some of our young talents stepped up to the challenge and that's exciting.'

The Australian shooter Kiera Austin was named Player of the Match with 24 goals and 15 assists.

England now travels to New Zealand for another three-Test series, which begins in Auckland on Sunday.

'But I'm very proud of our performance. It was a big step for us in our history. In the challenging Australian environmental conditions, I feel proud.'

Australian shooter Kiera Austin was named MVP with 24 goals and 15 assists.

England travels to New Zealand to play three more Test-Series, which begin on Sunday in Auckland.

This is the moment an Airbus Beluga dubbed the ‘world’s strangest-looking plane’ landed at Heathrow airport.

The Airbus Beluga, which got its name because of its resemblance to the species of whale, touched down at Heathrow Airport at 11:04 on Monday.

The Beluga has reportedly been dispatched from Toulouse with spare parts to repair a damaged British Airways plane that has been left stranded at Heathrow since April, after a minor collision at the airport.

The Airbus Beluga is due to leave Heathrow at 17:40 to return to Toulouse according to Flightradar24.

The victim is in a serious but stable condition in hospital

A man has been treated in hospital for serious injuries after he was stabbed in the stomach in Downpatrick, County Down.

Police said it happened on a pathway in St Dympna's Avenue in the town at about 18:00 GMT on Saturday.

The victim, aged in his 20s, is in a serious but stable condition in hospital, police said.

They added the suspect, believed to be a man in his 30s, left the scene on foot towards Oriel Drive.

They said he was wearing an all grey tracksuit and carrying a white plastic bag.

SDLP Cllr Conor Galbraith said it was a 'terrible incident and the local community are rightly shocked'.

'This is not what should happen in a peaceful community on a Saturday night,' he continued.

'I hope the injured party makes a full recovery and urge all involved to cooperate with the PSNI.'

Newly released CCTV footage shows floodwater raging through a library in Long Island, New York, causing about $10m (£7.5m) in damage.

The flood - on 19 August - was caused by heavy rainfall, and knocked down walls, swept away objects and destroyed centuries-old books and documents.

At the time, Suffolk County - where the library is located - and New York State declared a state of emergency, opening the door for federal assistance to help the rebuild effort.

In a post on its website, the library said the building will remain closed 'until further notice... while we continue to assess the damage and begin to rebuild'.

2.text:

The flooding, caused by heavy rainwater, tore down walls, carried away objects and destroyed century-old books and documents.

At the time of the incident, Suffolk County and the state of New York declared a state of emergency, paving the way for federal aid for the rebuilding efforts.

The library announced on its website that the building 'has been assessed for damage that is indefinite... The rebuilding process has begun.'

Former health minister and Conservative MP Daniel Poulter has defected to Labour, saying he disagreed with the Conservative Party's handling of the NHS.

In an exclusive TV interview with BBC's Laura Kuenssberg, the Central Suffolk and North Ipswich MP said the NHS 'deserves better'.

He said: 'I found it increasingly difficult to look my NHS colleagues in the eye, my patients in the eye, and my constituents in the eye with good conscience.'

Dr Poulter, who was first elected in 2010, served as a health minister for several years under the coalition.

You can watch his full interview on Sunday with Laura Kuenssberg, BBC One at 09:00 BST.

2.text:
Former Health Minister and conservative MP Daniel Poulter has joined the Labour Party as he disagreed with how the Conservative Party handles the NHS.

In an exclusive TV interview with Laura Kuenssberg of BBC, the MP for Central Suffolk and North Ipswich explained that the NHS 'deserves better.'

He said: 'It has become increasingly difficult for me to look my NHS colleagues in the eye, my patients in the eye, and my family in the eye, without a good conscience.'

Dr. Poulter, who was first elected in 2010, served as Health Minister several years under the coalition.

You can see his entire interview with Laura Kuenssberg, BBC One, on Sunday at 09:00 BST.

0.text:
Two women die and one man critical after crash

The crash happed on the A4050 in Barry, Vale of Glamorgan, near Pugh’s Garden Centre

Two women have died and two men have been taken to hospital, one in a critical condition, after a crash. It happened on the A4050 in Barry, Vale of Glamorgan, at about 13:40 GMT on Saturday, and the road closed from the junction of Port Road East and Barry Dock Link Road to Pugh’s Garden Centre. South Wales Police said two women died at the scene and two men are currently receiving treatment in hospital.

Sgt Craig Wood said: “First and foremost, our thoughts are with the family of the two women who have died in this collision. “We are in the early stages of our investigation and are still trying to establish the full circumstances.' He appealed for anyone driving in the area between 13:30 and 13:50 on Saturday who may have information to get in touch. 'We are particularly keen to hear from anyone who can give us extra detail on the manner of driving of a grey Audi RS 4 prior to the collision,' he added.

2.text:
He is looking for a contact person who provides detailed information about the driving behavior of a grey Audi RS 4 before the accident.

Two women are dead and a man is critical, two men were taken to the hospital following an accident on the A4050 in Barry, Vale of Glamorgan, near Pugh’s Garden Centre. This incident occurred around 13:40 GMT on a Saturday. The road was closed from the Port Road East junction to Barry Dock Link Road up to Pugh’s Garden Centre.

Sergeant Craig Wood stated: 'Our priority is with the families of the two women who lost their lives in this collision. We are still in the initial stages of our investigation and are working to gather all the facts.' He urged all those who were in the area between 13:30 and 13:50 on a Saturday and may have information to come forward. 'We are particularly looking for someone who can provide detailed information about the driving behavior of a grey Audi RS 4 before the accident,' he added.

0.text:
Tommie-lee Gracie Billington was found at a house on Greenset Close in Lancaster

The family of an 11-year-old boy who died after apparently taking part in a dangerous social media craze say they are 'devastated'.

Tommie-lee Gracie Billington died at a house in Greenset Close in Lancaster, Lancashire, on Saturday.

His grandmother Tina Burns said he had been at a sleepover taking part in a social media craze that involves sniffing or inhaling toxic fumes.

In a tribute to the schoolboy, she said she had 'never felt pain like this'.

Writing on Facebook, she added: 'I will make sure to the best of my ability that your name and your beautiful face will become the reason that other children's lives will be saved and other families don't have to suffer this deep, deep hurt.'

Police said the boy's death was being treated as unexplained and whether he had inhaled aerosols was one line of inquiry.

The force said previously the coroner had been informed.

Why not follow BBC Lancashire on Facebook, X and Instagram? You can also send story ideas to northwest.newsonline@bbc.co.uk

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.

2.text:
Tommie-lee Billington, an eleven-year-old boy, was found dead in a flat on Greenset Close in Lancaster, Lancashire, on Saturdays.

The family of the boy, who are believed to have been poisoned by harmful air fresheners due to a dangerous Social Media trend, are 'desperate.'

Tina Burns, the boy's grandmother, stated that he had participated in a Sleepover event, which involved inhaling aerosols as part of a Social Media trend.

In memory of the pupil, she wrote: 'I will do everything in my power to save children like yours with your beautiful face from such fate and families who will no longer have to endure this deep sorrow.'

The police are treating the death as unexplained, and whether he inhaled aerosols or not is currently under investigation.

The police had previously announced that the Judge President had been informed.

The boy's parents, who may have been poisoned by dangerous spray substances due to a hazardous Social Media trend, are 'desperate.'

The boy's grandmother, Tina Burns, announced that he had participated in a sleepover where inhaling spray cans was part of this Social Media trend.

In memory of the child: 'I will do everything in my power to protect children like yours with their beautiful faces and families, who are torn apart by this deep sorrow.'

The police are treating the death as unexplained, investigations are ongoing to determine if he inhaled sprays or not.

Previously, the police had informed the Judge President.

Stay with us on Facebook, X and Instagram, BBC Lancashire. You can also send us stories to northwest.newsonline@bbc.co.uk.

'Labour's secret tax rise dossier' and 'financial turmoil at IT giant'

This picture of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak on a boat made on to several front pages

Sir Ian McKellen is in 'good spirits' after falling off stage during a performance of Player Kings, a spokesperson said

Sir Ian McKellen's recovery after a fall off the stage earlier this week is featured in many of the papers. The 85-year-old lost his footing while performing in a fight scene during a performance of Player Kings in London. He's expected to return to the show tomorrow, with the Times, external, the Guardian, external and the Daily Mail, external all using variations of the phrase 'the show must go on' in their headlines. And the Sun says half of the Premier League trophy has been replaced, external after it was stolen. The paper says thieves in Belgium took a case containing the base and crown in late 2022, and it's believed the missing parts may have been melted down.

Sign up for our morning newsletter and get BBC News in your inbox.

Sir Ian McKellen is in 'good spirits' after falling during a performance of King Lear in London, according to a spokesperson.

The 85-year-old Sir Ian McKellen is on the mend after falling during a fight scene in a London production of King Lear. He is set to return to the theater tomorrow, according to The Times, The Guardian, and the Daily Mail. All three newspapers use the expression 'it must go on' in their headlines. The Sunday edition of The Sun reports that the top part of the Premier League Cup trophy has been stolen, external sources report. The thieves in Belgium are believed to have stolen the base and the crown sometime in early 2022, and it is suspected that the missing parts were likely melted down.

0.text:
The NFL has issued a security warning to players about a criminal network targeting their homes.

Players have been urged to ramp up security and take care about what they post on social media.

It comes after the homes of Kansas City Chiefs stars Patrick Mahomes and Travis Kelce were burgled last month, while a property owned by Dallas Cowboys' Linval Joseph was targeted last week.

An NFL security memo about the issue has been sent out to team security directors and the players' union.

Reporting on the memo, the NFL website said it was understood the criminal organisation 'use public records to find players' addresses and conduct extensive surveillance'.

'Then, by tracking team schedules and the social media accounts of players and their families, they wait until homes are empty - often during games.'

Players have also been asked to make it look like someone is at home when they are out, by leaving lights or a television on, for example.

'I can't get into too many of the details because the investigation is still ongoing,' Mahomes said when asked about the break in.

'But obviously something that you don't want to happen to really anybody, but obviously yourself.'

2.text:
The NFL has issued a safety warning to players as a criminal organization has targeted their homes.

Players were urged to increase security and be cautious with social media.

This follows break-ins at the homes of Patrick Mahomes and Travis Kelce of the Kansas City Chiefs, as well as the property of Linval Joseph of the Dallas Cowboys in the last month and the recent week.

An NFL security memorandum on the matter was sent to the security leaders of the teams and the players' union.

According to reports on the NFL website, the criminal organization uses public records to find players' home addresses and conduct extensive surveillance.

'They wait until the houses are empty - often during the games.'

Players were also advised to give the impression that someone is home by leaving lights on or turning on the TV.

'I'm sorry I can't say much more, as the investigations are still ongoing,' Mahomes said when asked about the burglaries.

'But apparently something that nobody wants to happen to them is happening to us.'

4.text:
The NFL has issued a security alert to the players, as a criminal organization is said to have targeted their homes. Players were advised to improve their security measures and be cautious with social media.

In the last month and week, the homes of Patrick Mahomes and Travis Kelce from the Kansas City Chiefs, as well as Linval Joseph's property from the Dallas Cowboys, have been burglarized.

An NFL security memo on this matter was sent to the security heads of the teams and the players' union.

According to reports on the NFL website, the criminal organization uses publicly available records to find players' home addresses and conducts extensive surveillance.

'They wait until the houses are empty - often during games,' the memo read.

Players were also advised to create the illusion that someone was home by leaving lights or the TV on.

'I'm sorry, I can't say much more, as investigations are ongoing,' Mahomes said when asked about the burglaries.

'But it seems like something that nobody wants to be a part of, our situation.'

Translation:

Die NFL hat die Spieler mit einer Sicherheitswarnung ausgestattet, da eine kriminelle Organisation ihre Wohnhäuser angegriffen hat. Die Spieler wurden aufgefordert, ihre Sicherheitsmaßnahmen zu verbessern und vorsichtig mit Social Media umzugehen.

In den letzten Monat und Woche wurden die Wohnhäuser von Patrick Mahomes und Travis Kelce der Kansas City Chiefs sowie Linval Josephs der Dallas Cowboys geburglt.

Ein NFL-Sicherheitsmemorandum zum Thema wurde den Sicherheitsleitern der Teams und der Spielergewerkschaft zugesandt.

Laut Berichten auf der NFL-Webseite nutzt die kriminelle Organisation offentlich verfügbare Aufzeichnungen, um die Wohnadressen der Spieler zu finden und ausführliche Überwachung durchzuführen.

'Sie warten, bis die Häuser leer sind - oft während der Spiele,' las das Memorandum.

Spieler wurden auch dringend aufgefordert

Holders Rangers will visit Celtic in the SWPL Cup semi-finals, with Hibernian facing visitors Aberdeen in the other last-four tie.

The games will be played on or before Sunday, 19 January.

Rangers, who beat Partick Thistle 4-1 in last season's final, had the biggest quarter-final win with Jo Potter's side defeating hosts Motherwell 8-1.

Celtic and Glasgow City could not be separated after 120 goalless minutes and Elena Sadiku's team triumphed 4-3 on penalties. They also host Rangers in Sunday's SWPL encounter.

Grant Scott's Hibs won 4-1 away to Thistle on Sunday and Aberdeen, with recently appointed boss Scott Booth in charge, also won on the road, 3-1 against Boroughmuir.

2.text:
Rangers face Celtic in the SWPL semi-finals, while Hibernian take on visitors Aberdeen.

The games will take place at the latest on Sunday, 19th January.

In the last season, Rangers defeated Partick Thistle with a score of 4:1. Their greatest success in the round of 16 was the result of Jo Potter's side, who beat Motherwell's home team 8:1.

Celtic and Glasgow City could not be separated after 120 minutes of play, and eventually, Elena Sadiku's team won with a score of 4:3 in a penalty shootout. They will face Rangers in the SWPL match on Sunday.

Grant Scott's Hibs won with a score of 4:1 against Thistle and Aberdeen, under new trainer Scott Booth, who also won with a score of 3:1 against Boroughmuir.

CCTV footage has captured brazen shoplifters and smash-and-grab raiders targeting stores on Edinburgh's Royal Mile.

Shopkeepers say the area has become 'lawless' with thousands of pounds' worth of goods stolen in recent months.

BBC News has obtained CCTV showing people walking out of shops with expensive cashmere scarves, jumpers and jackets in broad daylight.

One man can be seen kicking in a plate-glass window at night to steal armfuls of Harris Tweed bags, costing up to £150 each.

Staff say the area has become dangerous and intimidating, and that despite reporting thefts to police on an almost daily basis, nothing has been done.

Police Scotland says a dedicated team is working with businesses in the area and is investigating every report.

Oxford Street has switched on its annual Christmas lights display, becoming the first of the major London illuminations to be turned on for 2024.

More than 300,000 LED stars once again make up the lights, making them about 75% more energy efficient than standard lights.

It starts a season of events on Oxford Street including a partnership with Great Ormond Street Hospital's GOSH Charity.

Business groups hope the lights will provide a boost to retailers too as they gear up for the Christmas trade over the next seven weeks.

Follow BBC London on Facebook, external, Twitter, external and Instagram, external. Send your story ideas to hellobbclondon@bbc.co.uk, external.

Last updated on .From the section Football

Southampton have postponed Wednesday's Championship fixture with Preston North End following a major fire next to their St Mary's ground.

The club took the decision after consultation with local authorities and emergency services, with widespread disruption caused by the blaze.

Roads around the stadium are closed as fire crews continue to deal with the situation.

A new date for the rescheduled fixture will be announced in due course.

The blaze is in the industrial units on Marine Parade just yards from the ground.

The SNP leadership campaign got personal today.

But it's the Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross who fired the first shots at both leading candidates - and the SNP.

During the debate on the no confidence vote on the Scottish government, he said it looks like Nicola Sturgeon's Health Secretary (Humza Yousaf) will be replaced by her deputy (that's John Swinney) or her finance secretary (Kate Forbes).

Ms Forbes, he claimed, had raised taxes for Scottish workers and was “an even more radical nationalist' than Humza Yousaf or Nicola Sturgeon.

So far, so knockabout - prompting a bemused smile from Ms Forbes.

But then, the focus switched to Mr Swinney - or 'Honest John' as Douglas Ross called him - and then 'Not So Honest John'.

This earned a rebuke from the presiding officer - and Douglas Ross was forced to apologise.

Amid roars from fellow MSPs, John Swinney looked livid - wagging his finger at Douglas Ross - and voicing his anger.

But the first blows have been landed. And both leading candidates have been put on notice about what may lie ahead if they become first minister.

2.text:
The SNP leadership circle was personally attacked today, and Douglas Ross, chairman of the Scottish Tories, was the first to fire shots at both favorites and the SNP.

Speaking against the mood against the Scottish government, he mentioned that it seems the Health Ministry of Nicola Sturgeon (Humza Yousaf) will be replaced by her deputy (John Swinney) or her finance minister (Kate Forbes).

Ms. Forbes, he claimed, imposed taxes on Scottish workers and is 'a more radical nationalist' than Humza Yousaf or Nicola Sturgeon.

Everyone was surprised by a surprising smile from Ms. Forbes.

Then the attention turned to Mr. Swinney, or 'Honest John' as Douglas Ross called him, and 'Not So Honest John,' and he was attacked, leading to Douglas Ross apologizing.

With screams from other MSPs, John Swinney looked furious - and showed Douglas Ross the finger - and expressed his anger.

But the first blows had landed. And both favorites were asked what they could expect if they became First Minister.

Liverpool footballer Darwin Núñez was involved in an altercation with fans after his national team Uruguay were beaten by Colombia.

Disorder broke out close to where friends and family members of the Uruguay team were located, according to local media reports.

Video shows the striker physically confronting Colombia fans in the stands after the final whistle in the Copa America semi-final, which was being held at the Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, North Carolina.

Uruguay captain José María Giménez said the players were trying to defend their families, Reuters reported.

Núñez is yet to comment publicly on the incident.

Uruguay's captain, José María Giménez, stated that the players tried to protect their families, Reuters reported.

0.text:
The oldest person in Wales has celebrated her 112th birthday.

Mary Keir was surrounded by friends and family for a roast lunch followed by sherry trifle and then a buffet in the evening.

She spent the big day at Awel Tywi Residential Home in Llandeilo, Carmarthenshire, where she has lived for 12 years.

Mrs Keir is actively involved in life at the home, where she takes part in activities, entertainment and meetings.

Carmarthenshire council said she was also a keen lover of music, in particular the piano which had been a lifelong passion.

Mrs Keir worked as a ward sister and district nurse and lived in Llansteffan independently until just before her 100th birthday.

'Mary, our mother and mother-in-law still has a great will and determination,' her son Robert Keir and daughter-in law Sian Keir said in a statement.

'She has received fantastic care at Awel Tywi and we really appreciate everything that the amazing staff do for her every day,' they added.

Pupils from Ysgol Ffairfach, as well as Dinefwr Male Voice Choir, also visited the care home to celebrate.

Mrs. Keir is an avid music lover, especially the piano, which has been her passion throughout her life.

Mrs. Keir worked as a sister at the railway station and a nurse, living independently in Llansteffan until almost her 100th birthday.

'Mary, our mother and daughter-in-law, still has a great willpower and determination,' said her sons Robert Keir and daughter-in-law Sian Keir in a statement.

'She receives wonderful care at Awel Tywi and we thank all the excellent employees daily for everything they do for her,' they added.

0.text:
Nottingham Forest owner Evangelos Marinakis' appeal against a five-game stadium ban was dismissed to 'send a clear message' after he 'undermined respect for the game of football,' says the Football Association (FA).

The 57-year-old was found guilty of improper conduct for spitting on the floor as the match officials walked past following Forest's 1-0 Premier League defeat by Fulham at the City Ground on 28 September.

Marinakis denied the charge and appealed against the Regulatory Commission’s outcome, before it was later dismissed by an Appeal Board.

In a statement adding clarity to the appeal rejection, the FA said: 'Showing such contempt for match officials in a place where that can be seen by other individuals, significantly undermines respect for the game of football.

'Such behaviour is only more serious when it comes from an individual who himself has a position of both power and responsibility within the game.

'It is therefore vital that a clear message is sent that this behaviour will not be tolerated in any part of football.'

2.text:
Evangelos Marinakis, owner of Nottingham Forest, has rejected the appeal procedure for a five-game stadium ban, to send 'a clear message,' the Football Association (FA) stated after his unsportsmanlike conduct towards the match official.

The 57-year-old was punished for public obscenity, after he kicked the ground during Forest's 1-0 Premier League loss to Fulham on September 28 at City Ground, while referees were passing by.

Marinakis denied the accusation and filed an appeal against the decision of the Regulatory Commissions, which was later dismissed by the Appeal Court.

In a statement regarding the FA Appeal Judgment, Marinakis added: 'Behavior towards referees at public events harms the reputation of the game.

This behavior is more serious when it comes from a person who holds a power and responsibility position within the game.

Therefore, it is important that a clear message is sent that such behavior is in no way tolerated in football.

Marinakis denied the accusations and appealed the Disciplinary Court's judgment, which was later dismissed.

In a statement regarding the FA Appeal Court's decision, Marinakis commented: 'Misconduct towards referees at public events harms the reputation of sports. Such behavior is more serious when it is shown by someone who wields power and responsibility in sports. Therefore, it is important to clarify that such behavior is in no way tolerated in football.'

Schiedsrichter. Dieses Ereignis fand während des 1:0-Premier-League-Niederlagens von Nottingham Forest gegen Fulham am 28. September 2021 im City Ground statt. Marinakis, der 57 Jahre alt ist, wurde für dieses Verhalten bestraft.

Marinakis denies the allegations and withdrew his appeal before the FA Disciplinary Court. In a statement regarding the FA Disciplinary Court's ruling, Marinakis stated: 'Lawlessness towards referees at public events damages the reputation of sports. Such conduct is especially noteworthy when displayed by someone who holds power and influence in sports. It's crucial to remember that such behavior is unacceptable in football.'

0.text:
A London doctor is nearing the end of an intense training regime as he prepares to take on seven ironman triathlons in seven days for charity.

Dr Rob Mitchell, 32, who is from Hampshire but now lives in Tooting, south London, is raising money for men's health charity Movember, and the DMRC Benevolent Fund, which helps injured servicemen and women.

An ironman triathlon consists of a 2.4 miles (3.8km) swim, a 112 miles (180.2km) bicycle ride and a 26.2 miles (42km) marathon, with Dr Mitchell hoping to complete seven of them over seven consecutive days, starting on 18 August.

Follow BBC London on Facebook, external, X, external and Instagram, external. Send your story ideas to hellobbclondon@bbc.co.uk, external.

0.text:
Manchester United defender Luke Shaw has returned to training following three months out with injury.

The England left-back, who has not played for the club since February, sustained a calf injury in early August.

He had been expected to return after the international break in October but former manager Erik ten Hag said Shaw had suffered a 'setback'.

Shaw injured his hamstring in February which ruled him out of the remainder of the last Premier League season.

However, he was selected in England's squad for Euro 2024 and started the final defeat by Spain after missing the group phase.

United welcomed back Christian Eriksen and Mason Mount from injury during the side's 2-0 Europa League win against PAOK on Thursday.

Leny Yoro, a summer signing from Lille, is yet to make his competitive debut for the club after fracturing his foot in pre-season but is now back in training.

Interim manager Ruud van Nistelrooy says the club's injury problems are starting to ease.

'Christian played 30 minutes and Mason also played,' said Van Nistelrooy.

'It's beneficial for us and I'm happy that they're back. For the long-term absentees like Luke and Leny they are on the pitch with us.'

Manchester United's new signing from Lille, Lisandro Martínez, has not made his debut for his new team yet, as he sustained a foot injury during Manchester United's pre-season training. But he is now back in training.

Ruud van Nistelrooy, Manchester United's interim manager, commented on the decreasing injury list. 'Christian Eriksen played for thirty minutes, and Mason Mount is also back,' Van Nistelrooy said. 'That's a good end to the day for us, and I'm happy that they're back. They will help us bring long-term injured players like Luke Shaw's and Lisandro Martínez's back into the squad.'

0.text:
Knightsbridge is famous for its high-end shopping

A man has been charged with kidnapping and sexually assaulting a nine-year-old girl who was reported missing in Knightsbridge.

Robert Prussak, 56, appeared at Westminster Magistrates' Court earlier and was remanded in custody.

The girl was reported missing from Brompton Road, west London, at 14:44 BST on Monday and was found by officers at 17:40 in Old Court Place.

She and her family are being supported by police, detectives said.

Mr Prussak, of no fixed address, is also also charged with administering a substance with the intention of stupefying or overpowering to enable sexual activity.

He is due to appear at Isleworth Crown Court on 22 May.

0.text:
CCTV footage has been released showing the moment a stolen milk float crashed into a wall.

Rico Siddell and Luke Solomon assaulted the milkman while he was on his rounds in Basford, Nottingham, on 17 March 2022.

He was punched repeatedly to the head by both offenders and briefly lost consciousness.

Police later found the vehicle embedded in a wall in Tewkesbury Drive, with smoke coming from the bonnet and a pool of milk all over the street.

Both defendants were sentenced to two years in a young offenders institution, suspended for 21 months.

Follow BBC East Midlands on Facebook, on X, or on Instagram. Send your story ideas to eastmidsnews@bbc.co.uk.

2.text:
In English:

CCTV footage has been released showing a stolen milk truck crashing into a wall (recently).

Rico Siddell and Luke Solomon attacked the milkman in Basford, Nottingham, on March 17, 2022, as he was making his rounds.

Both suspects repeatedly hit the victims on the head and rendered them unconscious.

Later, the authorities found the vehicle in Tewkesbury Drive, with smoke coming from the cooler grill and milk spread all over the street.

Both defendants were sentenced by the Judge to two years of youth detention on probation, to serve for 21 months.

0.text:
One dead and five injured in York bus crash - police

Two air ambulances landed at the scene

One person has died and five others have been injured following a crash between a double decker bus and a car in York. Emergency services were called to Wetherby Road, near Rufforth, at 09:22 BST on Saturday. North Yorkshire Police said a 31-year-old man - a passenger in a Tesla - had died at the scene. The driver, a 32-year-old man, was taken to hospital with serious injuries. Three other passengers in the Tesla, along with driver of the bus, were treated for minor injuries.

The road was closed until 17:30 BST, police said

Two air ambulances joined three other ambulances and a Hazardous Area Response Team, as well as police, to deal with the incident. According to police, the deceased man is from the Newcastle area. The Tesla driver is from Teesside, the force added. The road was reopened at 17:25 BST. Anyone with information about the crash, or who has dashcam footage, is asked to contact police. Follow BBC Yorkshire on Facebook, external, X (formerly Twitter), external and Instagram, external. Send your story ideas to yorkslincs.news@bbc.co.uk, external

2.text:
In York, a collision occurred between a double-decker bus and a car, resulting in one death and five injuries. The emergency calls went to North Yorkshire Police at 09:22 BST on Saturday. A 31-year-old man, a passenger in a Tesla, was pronounced dead at the scene. The driver, a 32-year-old man, was taken to the hospital with serious injuries. Three other passengers in the Tesla and the bus driver were treated for minor injuries.

Two helicopters, in addition to three other emergency vehicles and a Hazardous Area Response Team, were deployed along with the police. According to the police, the deceased was from the Newcastle area. The Tesla driver is from Teesside, confirmed the police. The road section was closed until 17:30 BST, as the police announced.

Two helicopters, in addition to three other emergency vehicles and a Hazardous Area Response Team, were deployed along with the police. 4.text:
In York, there was an accident involving a double-decker bus and a car, resulting in one fatality and five injuries. The emergency calls went to North Yorkshire Police at 09:22 BST on a Saturday. A 31-year-old man, a passenger in a Tesla, died at the scene. The driver, a 32-year-old man, was taken to the hospital with severe injuries. Three other passengers of the Tesla and the bus driver were treated for minor injuries.

Besides the three emergency vehicles and the hazardous materials response team, the police were supported by two helicopters. According to the police, the deceased is from the Newcastle area. The Tesla driver is from Teesside, confirmed the police. The road section was closed until 17:30 BST, as announced by the police.

Besides the three emergency vehicles and the hazardous materials response team, the police were supported by two helicopters. According to the police, the deceased is from the Newcastle area. The Tesla driver is from Teesside, confirmed the police. The road section was reopened at 17:25 BST. Anyone with information about the accident or dashcam footage is requested by the police. Follow BBC Yorkshire on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and send your ideas to yorkslincs.news@bbc.co.uk.
