0.text:
Nottingham Forest captain Morgan Gibbs-White, manager Nuno Espirito Santo and Brighton boss Fabian Hurzeler have been charged by the Football Association following their red cards in Sunday's Premier League match.

Gibbs-White was dismissed in the 83rd minute after receiving a second booking, with the two managers sent off in the aftermath.

The Forest midfielder has been charged with acting in an improper manner and/or using abusive and/or insulting words towards fourth official Anthony Taylor.

Both Nuno and Hurzeler are charged with acting in an improper manner, with the Portuguese also alleged to have used abusive and/or insulting words towards a match official.

The trio have until Friday, 27 September to respond.

Gibbs-White was shown a second yellow card for a sliding challenge on Brighton's Joao Pedro with seven minutes remaining.

Hurzeler and Nuno, were dismissed by referee Rob Jones for their reactions to the incident on the touchline towards the end of the entertaining 2-2 draw, in which both clubs maintained their unbeaten Premier League starts.

Gibbs-White and Nuno will be missing for Forest's home league game against Fulham on Saturday, while Hurzeler will not be in the dugout when Brighton travel to Chelsea the same day (both 15:00 BST).

2.text:
Morgan Gibbs-White, captain of Nottingham Forest, Nuno Espirito Santo, trainer of Brighton, and Fabian Hurzeler were charged by the Football Association after receiving yellow cards in Sunday's Premier League match.

Gibbs-White received a second yellow card in the 83rd minute for a shooting attempt against Joao Pedro of Brighton and for unsportsmanlike conduct/abusive language towards the fourth official Anthony Taylor.

Both Nuno and Hurzeler were charged for unsportsmanlike conduct. Nuno additionally has to respond to allegations of abusive language towards a referee.

They have until Friday, 27. September to respond.

Gibbs-White was shown a second yellow card in the 83rd minute for a shooting attempt against Joao Pedro of Brighton with seven minutes remaining.

Hurzeler and Nuno were both sent off by referee Rob Jones for reactions to incidents on the touchline during the entertaining 2:2 draw, in which both teams maintained their unbeaten runs in the Premier League.

Gibbs-White and Nuno will miss Forest's home game against Fulham on Saturday (both 15:00 BST), while Hurzeler is not in Brighton's squad for the game against Chelsea on the same day (both 15:00 BST).

A judge has dismissed a lawsuit brought by a woman who accused Aerosmith singer Steven Tyler of sexually assaulting her twice in 1975 when she was 17.

US District Judge Lewis Kaplan said Jeanne Bellino waited too long to sue the 75-year-old rock star, according to the Reuters news agency.

Ms Bellino, a former model, claimed he had groped her in a Manhattan phone booth before pinning her against a wall later that day and simulating sex.

The judge decided the case did not qualify for a two-year window for submitting claims that would otherwise fall outside the usual legal time limit, because Tyler's alleged conduct did not meet the criteria for posing a 'serious risk of physical injury'.

Tyler's lawyer David Long-Daniels told Reuters: 'We agree with the judge's reasoning, and are grateful for this result on behalf of our client.'

The singer has also denied claims in a separate continuing case filed by another woman in 2022.

Officers made the vehicle pull over before escorting the couple to safety

An elderly couple who got lost in Manchester ended up driving around the city for 10 hours.

Police came to the aid of the pair, who had driven to Manchester from Wales and had been reported as lost.

They were spotted on the M60 and eventually stopped on the M62, with the driver said to be 'confused'.

Tweeting about the incident, Greater Manchester Police said it had given the pair a 'blue-light, first-class taxi back to safety'.

A shoplifting bird dubbed 'Steven Seagull' has been banned from a convenience store for flying off with packets of crisps over a six-year stealing spree.

Staff at the Lyndale Central store in Wyke Regis, Dorset, have put up posters urging customers to 'close the door' behind them in a bid to stop Steven.

The manager of the store, Stuart Harmer, said the crafty seagull had made off with about 30 packets of crisps in the past two months alone.

He said: 'Trying to explain to the powers that be that I've got stock loss because of a seagull - they think its a joke.'

Video from Russian television shows Americans Evan Gershkovich and Paul Whelan board a plane after their release as part of a prisoner exchange between Russia and the West.

Sixteen prisoners have been released from Russian prisons in the biggest exchange deal since the Cold War.

Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter, and Whelan, a US Marine veteran who also holds Canadian, British and Irish citizenship, are among those on their way back to the US.

Footage also shows Russian prisoners that were swapped in the exchange returning to Russia.

US President Joe Biden has celebrated the release of American prisoners, adding that the exchange was largely due to American allies.

0.text:
Emergency services were called to Burnt Oak Broadway on Thursday morning

A man has appeared in court charged with the murder of a woman who was stabbed near a bus stop in north-west London. The victim, aged 66, was treated by paramedics on Burnt Oak Broadway in Edgware on Thursday but died shortly before midday. Jalal Debella, 22, from Colindale, did not enter a plea at Willesden Magistrates' Court. He is due to appear at the Old Bailey on Tuesday. The Met Police previously said the attack was an 'isolated incident' and no further suspects were being sought. The stabbing happened close to the junction with Limesdale Gardens at about 11:50 BST. The woman's family has been informed.

The news was announced on his official Twitter/ X account by his family, who said Simpson 'succumbed to his battle with cancer' on 10 April and was 'surrounded by his children and grandchildren.'

They also asked for 'privacy and grace'.

You can read more about OJ Simpson's life and controversies here.

The editors of this page were Aoife Walsh, Siobhan Toman and Tiffany Wertheimer. The writers were Brandon Drenon, James Fitzgerald, Max Matza, Phil McCausland, Megan Fisher, Madeline Halpert, Joe McFadden and Suneil Asar.

Video footage shows the moment a lorry driver crashed in north Wales after being distracted by his mobile phone.

The dashcam and CCTV images show Raymond Catterall, 44, looking down at his phone before swerving the vehicle off the A55 at Tal-y-Bont, Gwynedd, and crashing in adjacent bushes.

He hits a stationary broken down car, as well as almost hitting three people and a dog stood on the grassy verge.

Catterall pleaded guilty to dangerous driving and using a handheld mobile phone whilst driving. He was given an eight-month suspended prison sentence, 150 hours of unpaid work, a three-month curfew and a 12-month driving disqualification at Caernarfon Crown Court.

The footage from the vehicle and CCTV cameras shows Catterall looking at his mobile phone before he lost control and collided into a row of closely growing shrubs.

He collided against a standing, defective vehicle and came very close to three people and a dog on the lawn.

Catterall admitted reckless driving and using a mobile phone while driving. In Caernarfon Crown Court, he received an eight-month suspended sentence, 150 hours of unpaid work, a three-month home confinement order, and a twelve-month driving ban.

0.text:
XL Bullies are now subject to restrictions in Scotland

An XL bully-type dog has been put down following an incident in North Lanarkshire.

Armed police were dispatched to Broughton Place in Coatbridge on Thursday amid reports the animal was out of control.

No shots were fired, but the dog was put down by a vet after being restrained by officers.

A 30-year-old woman was reported to the procurator fiscal in connection with an offence under the Dangerous Dogs Act.

No-one was injured in the incident, Police Scotland confirmed.

Restrictions on ownership of XL bully-type dogs were brought into force in Scotland last month.

Under the laws, the breeding and sale of the animals are now banned, while those already kept as pets must be muzzled in public places.

The legislation brought Scotland in line with similar measures put in place in England and Wales following concern over a series of fatal attacks.

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.

A 30-year-old woman was charged by the prosecutor with having a dangerous dog.

This law aligns Scotland with similar measures in England and Wales due to concerns over a series of fatal attacks.

Greater Manchester Police has recruited the biggest horse in the force’s 50-year history.

Named Trooper after a character in a Charles Dickens novel, the 10-year-old shire horse measures at 18.2 hands from the ground to shoulders.

Trooper has been described as a 'gentle giant', and the force said the horse would also take part in community events such as school visits.

'Everything size-wise even the bridle, rugs, stable has all got to be enlarged, just to accommodate his comfort,' trainer, Alistair Hunstone said.

Why not follow BBC Manchester on Facebook, X and Instagram? You can also send story ideas to northwest.newsonline@bbc.co.uk

Leicester have signed midfielder Oliver Skipp from Tottenham on a five-year deal for a fee in excess of £20m.

The 23-year-old, who came through Spurs' academy, made 77 Premier League appearances for the club, including 21 last season.

He will not feature when Leicester and Tottenham open their 2024-25 Premier League campaigns against each other on Monday at 20:00 BST.

'I'm really excited to sign. I've got the feeling that it’s a good group of people and a good group of players.' Skipp said.

'I'm sure that we’ve got a squad capable of challenging in every game. You look around the squad and there's lots of exciting players who have played in the Premier League and I’m really excited to see what this group can achieve.'

Skipp, who will link up with former Spurs team-mate Harry Winks, is Leicester's fifth summer signing after returning to the top flight.

Leicester said the former England Under-21 international would be available to make his debut on Saturday when they travel to Fulham.

Minutes before five women, who had been sexually abused by Mohamed Al Fayed, were due to appear on live TV, one of the group was vomiting in the studio toilets.

It would be Jen’s first time speaking about her experiences without the shield of anonymity - and she was terrified.

“I couldn’t eat that morning,” she recalls of the interview with BBC Breakfast at the end of September.

“I wasn’t very well practised at that point at telling my story and finding words. So I had a very physical reaction.”

About a week earlier, all five women's stories had been featured in a BBC documentary, Al Fayed: Predator at Harrods. The programme uncovered decades of abuse perpetrated by the billionaire and former Harrods owner, who died last year at the age of 94.

A town in the north east of Scotland has come together for a massive floodlit snowball fight.

Roxana Miskelly, 38, from Inverurie, said the idea was sparked on Monday after a huge amount of snow fell throughout the day.

Ms Miskelly said a call on social media saw a great turnout and the town squared up again on Tuesday night, with hundreds battling under floodlights at the local sports centre.

'Our idea has seemingly now started an epidemic of snowball fights breaking out all over the country, so we may not keep the title of Scotland’s Biggest Snowball Fight for long, but without a doubt we’ll be back at it next year, bigger and better!' she added.

It comes as an amber warning for snow has been issued for parts of Scotland after the country's coldest night of the winter.

CCTV footage shows the moment a car crashed into a café in Turin, Italy.

The incident happened around 9:30am local time, as customers were enjoying their breakfast inside the local coffee shop.

Seven people were taken to hospital with minor injuries, but there are no reports of casualties.

The speedometer on the car at the moment of the crash got stuck on 115km/h (around 71mph), according to local media.

'It could have been a real carnage, at least 10 people could have died,' Simona Carastro, the café owner's daughter told the BBC.

'Now we're just hoping that we'll be able to reopen the café as soon as possible, considering the extensive financial damage.'

Police are still investigating the circumstances of the crash.

Seven people had to be taken to the hospital, but there were no fatalities.

According to local media, the car's speedometer showed 115 km/h (approximately 71 mph) at the time of the accident.

'It could have been a real tragedy, at least ten people could have been killed,' Simona Carastro told the BBC. 'Now we hope to be able to reopen the café as soon as possible, depending on the extent of the damage to our property.'

The authorities are still investigating the cause of the accident.

0.text:
Hyperia is to reopen more than two weeks after it was closed

The UK's tallest rollercoaster is to reopen more than two weeks after it was closed following technical checks. Hyperia at Thorpe Park opened to the public on 24 May but stopped running the day after. In a statement on Tuesday, the theme park in Chertsey, Surrey, said: 'She may have needed a momentary pause after the most epic of launch events, but she's back in full flight'. The theme park said the ride will reopen to guests on Wednesday.

Hyperia is 236ft (72m) tall and has a top speed of 81mph (130km/h). The theme park said the closure followed 'standard technical pre-opening procedure checks', but has not given further details.

'One again we want to thank everyone for their understanding and patience,' a Thorpe Park spokesperson said. The theme park had previously told guests that it was unable to commit to reopening Hyperia before 8 June, adding last week that it was not possible to open the ride on that date.

Follow BBC Surrey on Facebook, external, on X, external. Send your story ideas to southeasttoday@bbc.co.uk , external or WhatsApp us on 08081 002250.

2.text:
Surrey, announced: 'She took a moment's pause after the epic opening events, but she is now back in operation.' The amusement park announced that the attraction would be accessible to visitors again on Thursday.

Hyperia is 72m (236ft) tall and reaches a top speed of 130km/h (81mph). The amusement park stated that the closure was due to 'routine technical pre-inspections', without providing further details.

'We would like to thank everyone for their understanding and patience,' said a spokesperson for the amusement park. The amusement park had previously informed visitors that it would not be possible to open Hyperia before June 8 and had announced weeks earlier that the attraction would not open on June 8.

0.text:
Thanks for joining us on our whistle-stop tour of new year celebrations around the world.

We've covered the major displays from Auckland in New Zealand, and the 12-minute extravaganzas in Sydney and Hong Kong.

Hundreds of thousands of people in Paris converged on the Champs-Élysées for an Olympic-themed party ahead of the 2024 Games in July. Central London hosted a firework display, which the organisers said was the biggest in Europe.

Vast crowds gathered at Copacabana beach in the Brazilian city of Rio de Janeiro to welcome in the new year. It's one of the world's biggest celebrations, attracting an estimated two million people.

And in Times Square in New York City, many thousands of revellers witnessed the famous ball drop to mark the moment.

You can dip into more coverage of the new year by reading our news story here

This page was brought to you by Aoife Walsh, Francesca Gillett, Emma Owen, Malu Cursino, James FitzGerald, Sam Horti and me.

Happy new year, one and all!

0.text:
Yes, but it’s hard to predict reliably which ones.

The various cars have specific strengths. McLaren struggled relatively in Austin, they believe, because there were only a couple of corners at the end of the Esses that played to their strengths in medium-speed bends.

By contrast, the Circuit of the Americas has a lot of high-speed corners, and braking from high-speed into low-speed, and low-speed. The first two of these characteristics are strengths of Red Bull, the last Ferrari.

McLaren expect the next couple of circuits in Mexico and Brazil to be better for them than Austin. And they have upgrades coming.

Qatar should be strong for McLaren; Las Vegas favours Ferrari. Abu Dhabi - Red Bull are always strong there. But Verstappen could have it tied up before then at this rate.

The cars are so close that other factors can come into play, too - who has a better weekend, driver performance etc.

2.text:
Yes, but it's difficult to choose those who make it.

McLaren had a hard fight in Austin, they believe, as only a few turns at the end of the Esses influenced their strengths in medium-speed bends.

However, in contrast, the Circuit of the Americas has many high-speed corners, and braking from high to low and vice versa. The first two of these features are strengths of Red Bull, the last of Ferrari.

McLaren expect the next two races in Mexico and Brazil to be better for them than in Austin. And they have upgrades coming.

Qatar should be strong for McLaren; Ferrari is expected to favor Las Vegas. Abu Dhabi - Red Bull is strong there. But Verstappen might be close as well.

The cars are so close together that other factors come into play, such as which team has a better weekend, performances of the drivers, etc.

McLaren had issues in Austin, only a few corners at the end of the esses affected their performance in medium-speed corners.

But the Circuit of the Americas is excellent due to many high-speed curves. The first two of these features are strengths of Red Bull, the last of Ferrari.

McLaren expect the next two races in Mexico and Brazil to run better for them than in Austin. And they have upgrades coming.

Yes, but it's difficult for the responsible parties to make the decision.

McLaren experienced issues in Austin, only a few corners at the end of the Esses affected their performance in medium-speed corners.

But the Circuit of the Americas is excellent, due to many high-speed corners. The first two of these points are strengths of Red Bull, the last one of Ferrari.

McLaren expect the next two races in Mexico and Brazil to go better for them than in Austin. And they have upgrades coming.

Catalunya should be strong for McLaren; Ferrari is expected to perform better in Las Vegas. Abu Dhabi - Red Bull is strong there. But Verstappen could also be a contender.

The cars are so close together that other factors come into play, such as the team that has a better weekend, driver performances, etc.

Catalunya should be strong for McLaren; Ferrari is expected to perform better in Las Vegas. Abu Dhabi - Red Bull is strong there. But Verstappen could also be competitive.

The cars are so close together that other factors come into play, such as the team that has a better weekend, driver performances, etc.

Terence Crawford won his fourth world title at different weights by beating Israil Madrimov to claim the WBA light-middleweight crown in Los Angeles. The 36-year-old American won by unanimous decision at the BMO Stadium to extend his unbeaten record to 41 fights. A former lightweight world champion who was also undisputed champion at light-welterweight and welterweight, Crawford triumphed 116-112, 115-113 and 115-113 on the judges' scorecards. Defeat was the first of 29-year-old Uzbek Madrimov's 11-bout career.

'Israil was a tough competitor,' said Crawford, who had not been taken to 12 rounds since 2016. 'He's real strong. He's durable. He took a lot of good shots. He got me to round 12. 'He had fast speed, a good rhythm upstairs. He was very disciplined and he fought a good fight. 'I was being patient. I didn't want to rush in with anything. That's how I got caught a couple times - I tried to eat too soon.' Crawford's win opened up the possibility of a fight with Mexico's super-middleweight champion Canelo Alvarez. 'If the money is right, we've got to fight,' said Crawford.
• None Notifications, social media and more with BBC Sport

2.text:
Terence Crawford won his fourth world championship in different weight classes by defeating Israil Madrimov in Los Angeles and capturing the WBA Middleweight belt. The 36-year-old American won by unanimous decision at the BMO Stadium, extending his win streak to 41 fights. The former lightweight world champion and undisputed champion in lightweight and welterweight, Crawford, won with scorecards of 116:112, 115:113, and 115:113. The first loss for the 29-year-old Uzbek Madrimov occurred in his 11th professional fight.

'Israil was a tough opponent,' said Crawford, who hadn't fought a 12-round bout since 2016. 'He is very strong. He is tenacious. He took many good shots from me. He put me in trouble in the 12th round. He had quick hand speed, good head movement, was very disciplined, and fought well. I was patient. I didn't want to force anything. That's how some of my meals are - I came on too strong.' Crawford's victory opened the door for a potential fight against Mexican super middleweight champion Canelo Alvarez. 'If the money is right, we'll fight,' said Crawford.

0.text:
A dust devil has been filmed dancing across a car park outside a cafe on an industrial park.

The phenomenon was filmed at KJ's Cafe in Marchwood, Hampshire, by Martin Somes on Thursday.

According to the Met Office, a dust devil is 'an upward spiralling dust filled vortex of air that may vary in height from a few feet to over 1,000'.

'They mainly occur in desert and semi-arid areas, where the ground is dry and high surface temperatures produce strong updrafts,' it added.

Although they resemble tornadoes, dust devils are not as powerful, but as they travel across the ground they can also carry other loose debris such as hay.

'Their main occurrence areas are deserts and semi-arid regions, where the ground is dry and high surface temperatures cause strong updrafts,' it added.

Police said the woman remains in custody

A woman has been arrested on suspicion of child neglect after three young siblings went missing.

Gloucestershire Police confirmed the three-year-old boy and the girls - aged five and eight - had now been found and were safe.

The children, who are from Cheltenham, were reported missing on Friday.

The force said the woman arrested in connection with the incident remained in police custody and thanked everyone who had helped find the children.

In a statement, a police spokesperson said 'Officers would like to thank everyone who shared our earlier appeal or submitted information on the children's whereabouts.'

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.

0.text:
George Galloway was not at the count in Rochdale

Veteran left-winger George Galloway has lost the Rochdale seat he won only four months ago in a stunning by-election victory. The Workers Party of Britain founder did not attend the count at Rochdale Leisure Centre to hear the general election result. Reform UK's Michael Howard came third, with 6,773 votes.

It was a huge turnaround from Mr Galloway's landslide by-election victory, when he tapped into anger about Labour's stance on the conflict in Gaza to win by more than 6,000 votes. His campaign in February was hugely boosted by Labour's decision to withdraw support for its candidate, Azhar Ali, over remarks widely alleged to be antisemitic. After his victory earlier this year, Mr Galloway said: 'Keir Starmer and Rishi Sunak are two cheeks of the same backside and they both got well and truly spanked.' Mr Galloway was a Labour MP until 2003, before sitting in the Commons as an independent and Respect Party MP for three constituencies between 2003 and 2015.

What questions do you have for the new government?

2.text:
George Galloway was absent during the counting at Rochdale's Leisure Centre for the Parliamentary election. The long-time left-wing activist lost the Rochdale constituency again, which he impressively won in the by-election four months earlier in a series of victories. Michael Howard from Reform UK came in third place with 6,773 votes.

A clear break from Galloway's landslide victory in the by-election, which was due to his outrage over Labour's stance on the conflict in Gaza and gave him over 6,000 additional votes. His campaign in February was significantly boosted by Labour's decision to dismiss their candidate Azhar Ali due to suspected anti-Semitic remarks. After his win the previous year, Mr Galloway had said: 'Keir Starmer and Rishi Sunak are two sides of the same coin, and both have had troubles.' Mr Galloway was a Labour MP until 2003, then sat as an Independent and Respect Party MP for three Commons seats between 2003 and 2015.

What will you ask from the new cabinet? (Question to the new cabinet)

He received over 6,000 additional votes. Michael Howard from Reform UK came in third place with 6,773 votes.

A significant deviation from Galloway's landslide victory in the by-elections, which was attributed to his indignation over Labour's decision to dismiss their candidate Azhar Ali due to suspected antisemitic comments, and brought him over 6,000 additional votes. 0.text:
An east London council is urging residents to dispose of hazardous waste properly after an empty gas bottle thrown in a household bin exploded in a refuse lorry, injuring a worker.

Footage captured in August, now released by Newham Council, shows the worker pressing a button on the side of a lorry before an explosion inside the truck blows a hole through the container.

The man can be seen bending over and running away following the blast, and the council said he had been 'rushed to the hospital with dizziness and hearing issues'.

Sarah Ruiz, Newham Council's statutory deputy mayor, said: 'We are grateful that our staff member is now recovering, but this incident could have been much worse.

'I urge everyone to be proactive and responsible, by taking these dangerous items to appropriate recycling locations.'

Listen to the best of BBC Radio London on Sounds and follow BBC London on Facebook, external, X, external and Instagram, external. Send your story ideas to hello.bbclondon@bbc.co.uk, external

In August, Newham Council published a CCTV image showing the man pressing a button on the side of the truck before the explosion in the truck pierced the bin.

The man is shown in the image with his back bent at the waist and running away afterwards, and the council stated that he was taken to the hospital with dizziness and hearing loss.

Sarah Ruiz, Newham Council's deputy: 'We are grateful that our employee has recovered, but this incident could have been much worse.

0.text:
A young urban ecologist has been making an impact on social media by creating videos to raise awareness about the animals that live in London.

Akash Barua, 24, from Peckham in south-east London, started to develop his love for nature when visiting family in Scotland and from there started to look at wildlife in the capital.

He has got a graduate ecologist position carrying out bat surveys, which usually means working at night, but in his free time he makes social media videos, including an Instagram series called 'Wild Endz' which has looked at the beavers in Ealing and the sparrows and parakeets of Peckham.

Follow BBC London on Facebook, external, Twitter, external and Instagram, external. Send your story ideas to hellobbclondon@bbc.co.uk, external.

2.text:
A young urban ecologist named Akash Barua, who hails from Peckham in southeastern London, has gained attention on social media platforms through videos that highlight animals in London.

A 24-year-old who lived in Scotland among relatives and discovered his love for nature there, later observed animals in the capital city.

He holds a doctoral fellowship in ecology, which means he typically works at night to study bats. In his spare time, he produces social media videos, including an Instagram series called 'Wild Endz,' which explores the foxes and rabbits of Ealing and the peacocks of Peckham.

Follow BBC London on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. Send your story ideas to hellobbclondon@bbc.co.uk.

Preston North End forward Milutin Osmajic has been charged by the Football Association with violent conduct after allegedly biting Blackburn Rovers defender Owen Beck.

Beck, who is on loan from Liverpool, was sent off in the closing stages of Sunday's goalless Lancashire derby for kicking out at Preston's Duane Holmes.

A melee followed, with Beck, 22, furiously protesting to referee Matthew Donohue that he had been bitten by Osmajic, who received a yellow card.

Television replays appeared to show 25-year-old Osmajic had bitten Beck on his upper back.

Osmajic has until Monday, 30 September to provide a response, the FA said., external

Luis Suarez, then of Liverpool, received a 10-match ban in 2013 for biting Chelsea's Branislav Ivanovic.

Blackburn manager John Eustace told BBC Radio Lancashire: 'Owen's got a big bite mark on the back of his neck and it's a shame the referee didn't see that.'

A witness examination can often play out like a game of chess: early moves will eventually set up a bigger play later.

Prosecutor Joshua Steinglass started off today by asking David Pecker about the times he’d personally witnessed Trump running his business.

Steinglass asked Pecker to describe Trump as a businessman. “Very knowledgeable, very detail oriented, almost a micro-manager,” Pecker replied.

And what was his approach to money like? “Frugal”, Pecker replies.

While this might seem flattering, prosecutors are likely trying to establish that Trump ran his business meticulously and was aware of how the Trump Organization spent his money.

Steinglass also asks if he ever saw Trump signing cheques, and if they were ever attached to invoices with staples or other means.

Pecker replied that he had watched Trump reviewing invoices and signing cheques, and recalled the corresponding items were often stapled together.

That detail might help prosecutors argue their claim that Trump in fact knew about the allegedly fraudulent way Michael Cohen was repaid for fronting the hush-money payment to Stormy Daniels.

On Monday, Trump’s lawyer asserted that the former president would not have had knowledge of that accounting process.

2.text:
And in regard to his money management? 'Frugal,' Pecker replied.

This could be seen as complimentary, as prosecutors may be attempting to prove that Trump carefully managed the Trump Organization's finances.

Steinglass further inquired if Pecker had ever witnessed Trump signing invoices and if they had ever been secured to invoices with nails or other means.

Pecker recalled Trump's presence during the inspection and signing of invoices, and he frequently remembered the accompanying articles being affixed with nails.

This detail might aid the prosecution's allegations that Trump was aware of the suspected fraudulent payment methods Michael Cohen employed in preparing the hush money payment to Stormy Daniels.

Trump's attorney declared on Monday that the former president was unlikely to have been informed about this accounting process.

Thousands of residents have been evacuated as large wildfires reached the suburbs of Athens, with flames as high as 25m (80ft).

The BBC's Jessica Parker is at the scene, where a huge plume of smoke can be seen coming from a timber yard.

Homes and properties - including a school - in nearby towns are on fire as the wildfires continued overnight.

Aircraft working to extinguish the flames were forced to land when the sun set, making it a ground operation overnight. Residents have complained of a lack of fire trucks and firefighters, and the Greek authorities have accepted offers of international assistance.

Read more on this story here.

The BBC's Jessica Parker is at the scene, where a massive smoke cloud can be seen coming from a timber yard.

Homes and buildings, including a school, in nearby towns are on fire as the wildfires continued overnight.

Firefighting aircraft were forced to land when the sun set, making it a ground operation overnight. Residents have complained of a lack of fire trucks and firefighters, and the Greek authorities have accepted offers of international assistance.

Translation:

Tausende Bewohner mussten evakuiert werden, als große Waldbrände die Vorstädte Athens erreichten und Flammen eine Höhe von bis zu 25m (80ft) hatten.

Die BBC's Jessica Parker befindet sich an der Stelle, wo sich ein großer Rauchwolke aus einem Holzlagerplatz erhebt.

In benachbarten Städten standen Wohnhäuser und Gebäude in Brand, darunter eine Schule.

Rettungslüftschiffe mussten notlanden, als die Sonne unterging, sodass es sich um eine Bodenoperation in der Nacht handelte.

Bewohner haben sich über den Mangel an Feuerwehrfahrzeugen und Feuerwehrleuten beschwert, und die griechischen Behörden haben Angebote internationaler Hilfe angenommen.

Thousands had to be evacuated as large forest fires drew near to Athens, with flames reaching a height of 25 meters. BBC correspondent Jessica Parker reported live from the scene where a massive cloud of smoke rose over a woodpile. Neighboring towns had houses and buildings, including a school, in flames. Firefighting planes had to land due to evening darkness, resulting in a ground operation during the night. Residents expressed concern over the insufficient number of firefighting vehicles and firefighters. The Greek authorities have accepted offers of international aid.

(In tausenden mussten Menschen evakuiert werden, weil große Waldbrände auf Athen zulieferten und Flammen eine Höhe von 25 Metern erreichten. BBC-Korrespondentin Jessica Parker berichtete lebendig von der Stelle, wo ein massiver Rauchwolke über einem Holzstapel aufstieg. Nachbarstädte hatten Häuser und Gebäude, darunter eine Schule, in Flammen. Feuerwehrflugzeuge mussten aufgrund der Abenddunkelheit landen, was zu einer Bodenoperation während der Nacht führte. Bewohner äußerten Besorgnis über die unzureichende Anzahl an Feuerwehrfahrzeugen und Feuerwehrleuten. Die griechischen Behörden haben Angebote internationaler Hilfe angenommen.)

Police dashcam footage has been released showing the moment a dangerous driver led officers on a high-speed chase.

Billy Ronchi, 22, was spotted driving 'erratically' and was pulled over by police in Cockington Road, Bilborough, Nottingham.

But when officers exited their car, Ronchi sped away, reaching speeds of about 70mph (112km/h) along residential streets, Nottinghamshire Police said.

Ronchi, of Baker Street, Derby, also passed through red lights and narrowly avoided crashing into a lorry.

The chase, which happened on 18 January, ended when Ronchi lost control of the car and crashed into a safety barrier.

He admitted dangerous driving, driving while disqualified and driving without a licence or insurance.

At Nottingham Crown Court, Ronchi was given a 16-month sentence, suspended for two years. He was also disqualified from driving for three years.

The force said Ronchi 'demonstrated a complete disregard for the safety of other road users when he sped through a built-up residential area in such a reckless manner'.

Storm Bert has brought heavy snowfall, rain and strong winds as it sweeps through parts of the UK, causing widespread disruption.

Snow has fallen across Scotland and parts of northern and central England, alongside the heavy rain and wind that has also hit southern England and Wales.

A number of yellow weather warnings remain in place after an earlier amber warning was lifted, and communities have been warned of flooding and power cuts.

Travel routes are heavily disrupted in some areas with trains cancelled and roads closed.

We've put together a selection of your pictures showcasing the weather around the UK, all sent into us through the BBC's Weather Watchers group. Scroll down to have a look.

Pioneering jockey Rachael Blackmore faces a spell on the sidelines after injuring her neck in a fall.

Blackmore, the first female rider to win the Grand National, was injured at Downpatrick on Friday.

'Rachael Blackmore has sustained a neck injury and will not ride in the coming weeks, while she undergoes rehabilitation for her injury,' said Irish Horseracing Regulatory Board spokesman Niall Cronin.

An exact diagnosis or timeframe for her return has not been given.

The 35-year-old was injured when parting company with her mount Hand Over Fist, trained by Denis Howard, in a handicap chase.

Blackmore was voted BBC Sports Personality's World Sport Star of the Year for 2021 after winning the National at Aintree on Minella Times.

She was also the first woman to be leading jockey at the Cheltenham Festival, where she won the Gold Cup the following year on A Plus Tard.

Blackmore had been tied at the top of of the Irish jump jockeys' championship before her injury, with 23 winners alongside Keith Donoghue and Sam Ewing.

A video released by the Philippine military appears to show Chinese and Filipino boats clashing in the contested waters of the South China Sea.

The Philippines has accused Chinese vessels of ramming Philippine boats, then boarding them and seizing weapons.

The country's top military commander General Romeo Brawner said Chinese coast guard personnel were armed with swords, spears and knives.

This appears to be an escalation, after a series of dangerous encounters, as the two sides seek to enforce their claims on disputed reefs and outcrops.

The confrontation took place as the Philippine navy and coast guard were delivering supplies to Filipino troops stationed in the Second Thomas Shoal, a decrepit navy ship used as a Filipino outpost.

Beijing said its personnel were professional and restrained, adding that they were aiming to block an 'illegal transportation' of supplies.

Read more on this story here.

0.text:
Transport for London, which is based at Palestra House in Southwark, said there was no evidence customer data had been compromised

Transport for London's (TfL) computer systems have been targeted in an ongoing cyber attack. It said there was no evidence customer data had been compromised and there was currently no impact on TfL services. Insiders have told BBC London they have been asked to work at home if possible, and that it is the transport provider's backroom systems at the corporate headquarters that are mainly affected. TfL’s chief technology officer Shashi Verma said: “We have introduced a number of measures to our internal systems to deal with an ongoing cyber security incident.'

He added: 'The security of our systems and customer data is very important to us and we will continue to assess the situation throughout and after the incident. 'Although we’ll need to complete our full assessment, at present there is currently no evidence that any customer data has been compromised. 'There is currently no impact to TfL services and we are working closely with the National Crime Agency and the National Cyber Security Centre to respond to the incident.”

2.text:
Transport for London (TfL) confirms in Southwark, England, that there is no evidence to suggest customer data were affected:

Transport for London (TfL) in England has been suffering from a cyber-attack for weeks. There is no evidence to suggest customer data were affected, and there was no impact on TfL services. BBC London reported that employees were advised to work from home where possible, and that TfL's headquarters systems were hit the hardest. TfL's Chief Technology Officer Shashi Verma stated: 'We have introduced numerous measures to our internal systems to deal with a live cyber security incident.'

He added: 'The security of our systems and customer data is of utmost importance to us, and we will continue to assess the situation during and after the incident.' Although we are undergoing extensive testing, there is currently no indication of customer data breach. 'There was no impact on TfL services, and we are working closely with the National Crime Agency and the National Cyber Security Centre to respond to the incident.'

0.text:
The previous owner said he had 'treasured' the goat all his life

A pottery goat made by King Charles has sold for £8,500. The small ceramic animal, which had been treasured for 55 years by Canadian Raymond Patten, was auctioned in Staffordshire on Tuesday. It was given to him on his 21st birthday by a great aunt who worked as a cook at Cambridge University. 'I believe she knew the future King on a personal basis. I have treasured the goat all my life,' Mr Patten said.

Mr Patten said his aunt 'told me Prince Charles had made it'. He added: 'She was proud of the fact he attended Cambridge University in the late 1960s when she worked as a cook for the president of Queens' College.' Charles Hanson, of Hansons Auctioneers, added: 'Raymond decided to part with the goat due to its historical significance. 'He is in his retirement years and wanted to find it a new home where it would be treasured for decades to come.' Follow BBC Stoke & Staffordshire on Facebook, external, X, external and Instagram, external. Send your story ideas to: newsonline.westmidlands@bbc.co.uk, external

Charles Hanson from Hansons Auctions commented: 'Raymond gave up the figurine due to its historical significance. He had retired and wanted it to find a new home where it would be revered for decades.'

Charles Hanson of Hansons Auctions commented: 'Raymond gave up the figurines for their historical significance. He was retired and seeking a new home for them, where they were revered for decades.'

Follow BBC Stoke & Staffordshire on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram. Send your story ideas to: newsonline.westmidlands@bbc.co.uk.

0.text:
A disabled woman says when the lift in her block breaks, she is often forced to sleep under the stairwell downstairs.

Joanne Scott lives in the Silwood Estate in Rotherhithe, south-east London, and says the lifts have broken down 67 times in the past year.

The housing association L&Q disputes the number of times the lift has broken down and how long it has been out of action during that time.

David Lewis, executive group director – property services at L&Q, added that the firm was 'very sorry for the problems that Ms Scott and the residents have experienced with the lift and recognise this has taken us too long to put right.

'All electrical and mechanical lift components are being replaced to ensure that it meets the highest standards and provides a long-term reliable service - our aim is to have this work completed by the end of this year.'

Follow BBC London on Facebook, external, Twitter, external and Instagram, external. Send your story ideas to hellobbclondon@bbc.co.uk, external.

2.text:
A disabled woman from Rotherhithe's Silwood Estate in southeastern London claims that the elevators in her building frequently malfunction, forcing her to sleep on the landing above.

Joanne Scott lives in the housing complex and claims that the elevators have broken down a total of 67 times in the last 12 months.

The housing association L&Q disputes the given numbers and the duration of the failures during this period.

David Lewis, L&Q's Executive Director of Customer Services, adds: 'We deeply regret that Mrs. Scott and the residents have experienced problems with the elevator and that this has lasted for so long.'

'All electrical and mechanical elevator components are being replaced with new parts to maintain the highest standards and ensure long-term reliable service - our goal is to complete this work by the end of the year.'

Follow BBC London on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram. Send your story ideas to hellobbclondon@bbc.co.uk.

0.text:
Police have released dashcam footage of the moment a car collided with an oncoming vehicle.

The incident happened on 1 January 2023 in Peterborough.

Djiferson Monteiro, 35 of Deer Park Way, Thorney, pleaded guilty failing provide a specimen of blood for analysis, dangerous driving and driving without insurance.

He was sentenced at Cambridge Crown Court to eight months in prison, suspended for 18 months and disqualified from driving for two years, when he will be required to retake a test.

He must also complete a 20-day rehabilitation activity requirement and undertake 120 hours of unpaid work.

Follow East of England news on Facebook, Instagram and X. Got a story? Email eastofenglandnews@bbc.co.uk or WhatsApp 0800 169 1830

This incident occurred on January 1, 2023 in Peterborough.

Djiferson Monteiro, 35, from Deer Park Way, Thorney, admitted to not providing a blood sample for analysis, reckless driving, and driving without insurance.

He was sentenced at Cambridge Crown Court to eight months of probation for 18 months and a two-year driving ban, during which he must retake his driver's license test.

He also must complete a 20-day rehabilitation program and perform 120 hours of unpaid work.

'I've got some proper Halloween scars on this one.'

MMA fighter Paddy 'The Baddy' Pimblett points to the marks left by three operations on his foot. He's had another three on his hands.

'My body is falling apart at 29 - but I've been fighting since I was 15,' he says.

'I just get on with it.'

The Next Generation Gym is where he gets on with it.

Pimblett and Molly 'Meatball' McCann, 34, are the two highest-profile members of a tight-knit MMA fighting community at the renowned Liverpool gym.

It is where both are preparing for fights in Manchester later this month; contests which could be significant to their careers after 18 months of turbulence, headlines and life changes.

They are part of a wider, longer-term project though.

Their training is led by head coaches Paul Rimmer and Ellis Hampson, who joined forces 20 years ago to build an MMA community and a lasting legacy for Liverpool.

For now, there’s a sigh of relief, a pause.

Israel’s limited strike, not officially acknowledged, has given space to Tehran. In this grey area, its leaders are casting it as a slap so weak it’s not even clear who did it. They don’t lose face after days of declarations vowing that even the tiniest Israeli invasion would provoke an immediate and harsh response.

Many had predicted Israel would wait until after Passover to retaliate. It appears to have decided it needed to hit sooner, to send a clear signal, just before the holiday starts. It may still strike again, in a different place, with different force, when this period ends.

But as my colleague Jeremy Bowen writes, this crisis really illustrates how badly Iran and Israel understand each other.

This may have been just a warning salvo into the beating heart of Iran, the province of Isfahan with its stunning Islamic architecture but also a nuclear facility, a major air base, the industrial heartland including drone and ballistic missile factories.

This round may be over, for now, but the seething hostility between two regional rivals is not.

2.text:
For the time being, there is calm, a pause.

Israel's unexpected limited attack gives Teheran an opportunity. In this uncertain situation, their leaders will see it as a weak blow with uncertain origin. They will uphold their reputation by promising immediate and heavy counter-attacks, regardless of the invasion size.

Many had expected Israel to respond after Passover. Israel seems to have struck earlier, sending a clear message, right before the celebrations. It could strike again, with greater force, once this phase is over.

However, as my colleague Jeremy Bowen puts it, this crisis moment underscores the poor understanding between Iran and Israel.

This exchange may be over, for the time being, but the intense hostility between these regional rivals persists.

Translation:

At present, there is calm, a pause.

Israel's unannounced limited attack provides Tehran with an opportunity. In this unstable situation, their leaders will view it as a weak blow with uncertain origin. They will maintain their reputation by promising immediate and heavy counter-attacks, regardless of the invasion's size.

Many had anticipated that Israel would respond after Passover. Israel appears to have struck earlier, sending a clear message, just before the festivities. It could strike again, with greater force, once this phase is completed.

However, as my colleague Jeremy Bowen points out, this crisis moment highlights the poor communication between Iran and Israel.

This exchange may have ended, for the time being, but the intense animosity between these regional adversaries continues.

“Oh god! We’ve got a Labour government!” A delighted member of the Cabinet told me reality only finally hit them when driving through their constituency on Friday, more than a week after voters sent the Tories packing.

In the prime minister’s first seven days he’s been confronted with a deeply awkward situation abroad – President Joe Biden’s competence dominating the NATO summit.

At home the justice secretary has felt compelled to plan early prisoner releases (it’s unusual a politician would make a willing choice to do that), and doubts over the survival of the steel plant in Port Talbot linger.

In other words, Labour is already grappling with the tasks government requires them to do – not the options they would choose.

But on Wednesday their own plans will take centre stage, with all the fuss and fanfare Westminster can summon – the attendance of the King, the giant golden throne (yes, really!), the trumpets, the frills and flounces.

The first ‘King’s Speech’ will list the law the government hopes to pass in its first year of what Labour already hopes will be a decade in charge.

2.text:
Wowwah! We have a Labour government! - A happy cabinet member told me that her reality was secured on Friday, more than a week after voters dismissed the Tories.

In the first weekend days of the Prime Minister, he found himself in an awkward situation - President Joe Biden's competence overshadowed the NATO summit.

At home, the Justice Minister felt the need to plan early releases for parolees (rare for a politician who voluntarily chooses this), and the future of the steelworks in Port Talbot remained uncertain.

In fact, Labour is already dealing with the tasks assigned to them by the government, not the choices they would make.

But on Thursday, their own plans take center stage, with all the fanfare and pomp that Westminster can offer - the presence of the King, the golden throne, indeed!, the trumpets, the regalia, and the splendor.

The first 'Royal Speech' will show the laws the government intends to pass in its first year, full of hope to rule for a decade.
